HEADLINE: Waterfront Project Hinges on Asphalt Plant

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN 

 BODY:
WHEN developers working to rehabilitate an old industrial section of this village acquired a neighboring waterfront parcel occupied by an asphalt plant, it was considered a major coup. Ultimately the project will give the village new offices, a new public works garage and a new recreational center, making a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to remake a large swath of Hudson River waterfront near the border with Sleepy Hollow, as well as significant parts of the village.
 ''We were able to acquire the entire property, which we never expected,'' said Joseph Cotter, president of Ferry Landings, a development project by National Resources of Greenwich, Conn. 
 But the developer's attempts to relocate the county asphalt plant to a site about 400 feet from where it sits is quickly becoming a problem for the project, which calls for 88 town houses, a new village hall, the new public works garage, a recreation complex including an aquatic center as well about 150,000 square feet of office and retail space. 
 At a meeting Tuesday night, Tarrytown residents lined up to question the planning board's handling of the asphalt plant move, while complaining about an overall lack of information regarding the project and calling for further study. 
 ''What was discussed tonight sounds like a possible improvement, but I'd like to make that judgment when I see the final design,'' said Cherie A. Gaines, a Tarrytown resident who also expressed concerns about the density of the project.
 The Tarrytown development is one of several in various stages of planning along the Hudson River waterfront from Yonkers to Peekskill. For much of the last century, a great deal of waterfront land was used for industry, and the municipalities that are now able to plan developments there have encountered various challenges like density and size, environmental concerns, aesthetics, green space and access to the river. 
 The Tarrytown meeting came just days after neighboring Sleepy Hollow filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court in White Plains seeking to overturn Tarrytown's decision to forgo a full-scale review of the move under the State Environmental Quality Review Act and challenging zoning changes and site plan approvals related to the Ferry Landings project.
 ''The village is not necessarily opposed substantively to what the Village of Tarrytown is doing,'' said Joel H. Sachs, a lawyer with Keene & Beane who is representing Sleepy Hollow. ''But their concerns are that there are procedures under state law that require that all the environmental and land use impact of development proposals be given a hard look under the environmental review law SEQRA.'' 
 That law, the State Environmental Quality Review Act, requires state or municipal agencies weighing projects to consider the environmental impacts against social and economic factors. If a project is deemed to have no significant impact, the agency can make a ruling called a ''negative declaration'' and forgo producing a full environmental impact statement.
 Mr. Sachs said Tarrytown has been going about the process using what he calls the ''salami approach,'' slicing off bits of the projects and granting approvals without an overall environmental assessment of the project.
 Tarrytown officials responded that a draft environmental impact statement for the Ferry Landing project is in the works, but that a full environmental review on moving the asphalt company was not necessary because the plant already exists, and because village officials had determined that no negative impact would be created by moving it. 
 ''The people contesting us are treating this as if it is a new plant,'' said Dr. Stanley L. Friedlander, chairman of the planning board. ''The asphalt plant exists, the environment it produces exists, and the question is, does moving it 400 feet have a negative impact.''
 Mr. Friedlander said that upgrades related to the move will make the plant more environmentally friendly. He also noted that officials are pressing to move the project ahead quickly because federal officials have found the current village hall unsuitable for use, so there is pressure to get the new village hall under construction.
 ''It's second best but we really think it's an improvement to the existing conditions,'' Mr. Cotter said at the meeting. In an ideal world, he said, the asphalt plant would find a home outside the new development. At this point, such a move does not seem likely because the plant has a 99-year lease to operate and has said it would remain in the current area.
 But residents said they feared the village has not done its homework and has failed to look at issues like the impact on neighborhoods that will be closer to the plant, owned by Peckham Industries, after the move and the possibility that it might increase production once it had been upgraded.
 Ray Touey lives on Storm Avenue, which will be even closer to the plant after the move. He spoke up Tuesday night, saying he had been watching the meeting on television and became so concerned he got in his car and drove to the meeting to address the planning board.
 Mr. Touey told the board that he was concerned that emissions from the plant could adversely affect his 10-year-old daughter, Kaitlyn, who has asthma. He said that from what he had heard there was no adequate evidence to assure him that would not be the case.
 ''All I keep hearing is 'I think, I think,''' he said.
 Ultimately, the planning commission postponed voting on whether to approve the asphalt plant relocation for a month to give Mr. Touey and other residents an opportunity to review the environmental information compiled on the plant. Mr. Friedlander encouraged residents who had health and safety concerns to present them to the appropriate agencies.
 As the audience continued to press the board about details of the project, Mr. Friedlander suggested that they might be better served if they were to begin attending Sleepy Hollow meetings regarding development on the old site of the General Motors plant where more than 1,500 units of housing are being proposed.
 ''If all of us are so concerned about Tarrytown we should all be at the Sleepy Hollow meetings,'' he said.
 In a telephone interview, Mr. Cotter suggested that Sleepy Hollow was using the lawsuit to try to delay the Tarrytown project to give its own a leg up. He called the suit disingenuous, saying Sleepy Hollow had agreed not to file a suit immediately, after Tarrytown agreed that the window for filing an action could be extended.
 ''It's gravely disappointing and we think very much in bad faith,'' Mr. Cotter said.
 Mayor Philip Zegarelli of Sleepy Hollow noted that the negative declaration made by Tarrytown could be challenged only for 30 days. Despite the offer of an extension, he said, there were concerns that the agreement did not provide adequate protections for the village, which has a new development -- Ichabod's Landing -- near where the plant would be moved. He also expressed concerns that Tarrytown, in moving so quickly with approvals, was trying to get ahead of Sleepy Hollow.
 Beyond that, however, he said that the revitalization along the Hudson, an opportunity that comes along only about once every 100 years, warrants extreme caution and care.
 ''We're at a crossroads now and in looking at the asphalt plant every effort should be made to see about eliminating it,'' he said.
 For groups like Scenic Hudson, which is working with communities in an attempt to create well-thought out developments, the escalating ill will between the communities is cause for concern.
 ''I think both Tarrytown and Sleepy Hollow have a once-in-a-generation opportunity to shape a highly visible and crucial portion of Westchester County on the waterfront,'' said Ned Sullivan, the executive director of Scenic Hudson.
 Between the two communities he said there are roughly 130 acres including a 1.8-mile stretch of waterfront. But in an area already choked with traffic, the challenge is to use the land wisely and with full understanding of the future impact.
 ''If the two mayors could be working collaboratively and trying to address these proactively,'' Mr. Sullivan said, ''we would end up with two or three waterfront projects that work well together, that minimally impact traffic and insure public access along the water.''

HEADLINE: Agency Plans to Reap Wind Power Off Jones Beach

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Imagine a modern windmill, sleek and metallic.
 Make it giant-sized -- specifically 425 feet tall, equal to a 40-story building and taller than the Statue of Liberty.
 Now picture 35 to 40 such windmills, all standing in the Atlantic Ocean, clustered near Jones Beach.
 The Long Island Power Authority says it will soon start turning that imaginary scene into reality, to harvest electricity from the steady sea breezes that have drawn people, from the ancient Indians to modern suburbanites, to the shoreline.
 The authority says that in the coming weeks it will announce its choice of the company to build and operate the windmills. Officials will not identify the bidders, but industry sources say the two leading contenders are Arcadia Windpower Ltd., based in Manhattan, and FPL Energy, based in Florida. The project could produce the first offshore windmills outside of Europe, wind power experts say. While land-based windmills are increasingly common around the world, offshore sites are relatively new. 
 A larger proposal for 130 offshore windmills is pending on Cape Cod, but residents have mounted a $1 million campaign to block it, citing economic, environmental and scenic concerns. Some Long Islanders have raised similar objections, but so far there is little organized opposition.
 The Long Island project would cost hundreds of millions of dollars and take up to four years, authority officials say. The exact price and other details will be announced later. ''At a time when oil prices are going through the roof, this makes imminent sense,'' said the agency's chairman, Richard M. Kessel.
 Those rising prices forced the authority to impose fuel surcharges on electricity customers. Growing demand for power is also forcing the purchase of new generators and supply cables, so the authority is facing greater expense and more disputes over sites. And Gov. George E. Pataki is requiring the use of more clean energy, though it costs more than power from fossil fuels in the current market.
 The windmills would represent only about 2 percent of the authority's total power use, and so would have a minimal impact on electricity bills. 
 Many environmentalists, including some who criticize the authority on other issues, have long advocated windmills. ''Windmills are a necessity, not only for Long Island, but for the state and nation,'' said Adrienne Esposito, executive director of the Citizens Campaign for the Environment, one of several groups endorsing the project.
 Windmills use a limitless resource without harming the environment, supporters say. Wind energy also reduces dependence on Middle East oil with its gyrating prices and volatile politics. ''The fuel is free from Mother Nature, and the cost is predictable,'' said Gordian Raacke, executive director of two energy groups, the Citizens Advisory Panel and Renewable Energy Long Island. 
 Still, the plan poses a host of concerns. Skeptics cite noise and vibration, dangers to migrating birds, disruption of prime squid fishing, and intrusive underwater cables and power connections on land.
 Most of all, critics have focused on the permanent alteration of the ocean view from the South Shore.
 But authority officials said the impact would be minimal on birds, fish and even the view. Because the windmills would be 2.5 to 6 miles from shore, they would appear small on the horizon, proponents contend.
 While the precise location has not been decided, the windmills would be somewhere off the coast of Jones Beach and possibly Long Beach or the western end of Fire Island.
 Jones Beach is jammed on hot summer weekends. Long Beach and neighboring communities are the most densely populated stretches of oceanfront in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Fire Island has a major park and summer resort.
 ''Why Jones Beach rather than anywhere else on the South Shore?'' said Joseph M. Kralovich, president of the Old Lindenmere Civic Association in Merrick. ''It's a sore subject, but the answer is obvious. It's to avoid people with expensive waterfront homes. Nobody lives there.'' He opposes the windmill plan. ''I moved here from the city because of Jones Beach, to get closer.''
 Another critic, Cathy McGrory Powell of Wantagh, said: ''Jones Beach is a big tourist center. It's going to be horrible. Why, instead, isn't every government building using solar energy and every official driving a more fuel-efficient car?''
 The power authority says it chose the site because the water is shallow, the winds average about 19 miles an hour, and an existing substation in nearby Massapequa would connect to the windmills, serving densely developed Nassau and western Suffolk.
 Windmill defenders call the view a minor issue. ''We have to make a choice: whether we want to look at smokestacks or windmills,'' said Mr. Raacke, of Renewable Energy Long Island. ''It's worth paying that small price.'' He said he had found no opposition to offshore windmills in Europe, adding, ''People are quite proud of them, actually.''
 Ms. Esposito, of the Citizens Campaign for the Environment, said windmills would become a tourist attraction, as they have elsewhere. ''If acid rain and smog keep up, we're not going to have a view, anyway.''
 Last month, Hofstra University, whose campus displays a miniature windmill in tribute to Nassau County's Dutch heritage, held a conference titled ''From Blackouts to Windmills.'' Richard V. Guardino Jr., dean of suburban studies and a resident of Point Lookout, near Jones Beach, said, ''Personally, I like the way windmills look, and I think they would add something.''
 As a sun worshiper, the authority's chairman, Mr. Kessel, said: ''No one loves Jones Beach or goes there more often than I do. A passing tanker ship is going to be a lot more visible than these windmills that you can barely see. It'll be a comforting sight, dedicated to a cleaner environment for Long Island.''
 Some fishing companies, though, are opposed. ''Some of our largest catches are right there in the area they're talking about,'' said Sima Freierman, general manager of Montauk Inlet Seafood, which unloads, packs and transports fish. ''There's enough places on land where they can do this.''
 Ms. Freierman said more than two million pounds of squid were netted by trawlers from New York in the planned windmill site each summer, as well as catches by boats from other states. The site also yields millions of pounds of bluefish, butterfish, flounder, fluke, monk and whiting. For boats, ''putting windmills there is like putting concrete poles in the middle of the Long Island Expressway,'' she said.
 But proponents of windmills say they will use only about five square miles, a small part of the fishing grounds. Windmills could act as an artificial reef and a preserve that would help replenish fish stocks, said Prof. Malcolm J. Bowman of the marine science center at Stony Brook University. Many recreational fishers are keen on the windmills, which they say will attract fish. 
 Before the windmills are built, more public hearings will be held, and 18 official approvals are required from various state and federal agencies, including the Federal Aviation Administration, which will require blinking warning lights.
 Each steel tower will rise 425 feet from the ocean surface to the top of the arc swept by the three rotating resin blades. Depending on the location, 40 to 70 feet of the tower will be underwater. The base will go an additional 60 to 80 feet underground into the seabed. The towers will be 15 to 30 feet thick at water level and placed a third of a mile to half a mile apart, according to the authority's project manager, Daniel Zaweski. The blades will rotate 8 to 20 times a minute, swiveling and tilting to catch the wind, and generate 3.6 megawatts of power. The entire group will generate 100 to 140 megawatts, enough for 30,000 homes. 
 The critics' biggest fear seems to be that if the windmills succeed, more will go up. ''If this works, they're talking about stringing this along the entire South Shore, putting us out of business,'' Ms. Freierman said.
 Mr. Kralovich expressed a similar fear: ''Once they put this in, wind farms are going to go in, up and down the East Coast. In 30 years, it's going to look like the Jersey Turnpike.''
 But Mr. Kessel is taking a shorter view. ''We want to take this one step at a time,'' he said. ''It's a project that's never been done before in North America, and we want the public to see it and give acceptance, which I think they will, before we even look at expansion.''

LENGTH: 747 words

HEADLINE: Unstained Masses

BYLINE: By Rob Walker

 BODY:
Jonathan Levine calls himself ''an aesthetic dentist.'' He has been in the business for 22 years, specializing in prosthodontics, which is the restoration and replacement of teeth. Over time, working in New York City, he gradually built up a list of famous clients; he is, in fact, what could be called ''a celebrity dentist,'' the kind who is quoted about Sarah Jessica Parker's teeth in USA Today. It was for such people, who basically look good for a living, that he began noodling around a few years ago with a method for portable tooth-whitening. 
 It did not, at first, occur to him that there would be any demand for his invention -- an ampule that lets you smear a hydrogen-peroxide-based whitening mixture onto your teeth -- among those who do not have to worry about how they look on Entertainment Tonight. But whether it's true that no one ever went broke by underestimating the taste of the American public (as H.L. Mencken rather tastelessly contended), it's lately seeming much harder to go broke by overestimating the vanity of the American public. Levine's invention has evolved into a product called GoSmile, which is described as offering ''prestige smilecare.'' GoSmile is now sold in fancy department stores like Henri Bendel, Fred Segal, Saks and the Sephora beauty chain. Last year it had sales of around $2 million, and it's on track to hit $8 million this year. 
 It was Levine's wife, Stacey, who had run a luxury corporate-gift business, who thought GoSmile had commercial potential, at least at the high end. ''It looked like a real lifestyle opportunity,'' she says. Then two things happened that brightened 
 GoSmile's potential. Word spread from some of Levine's clients to makeup artists, who passed the word to their clients. And Crest and Colgate rolled out enormous marketing campaigns for similar products aimed at what Mencken might have called the Great Unwhitened. This created a mainstream, $330 million category and established something for GoSmile to be more exclusive than. Deborah Walters, a Saks senior vice president, says she had seen doctor-developed skin-care brands become hits and ''immediately'' saw the potential for 
 GoSmile as the driver of a new high-end beauty category. A package of 56 Crest Whitestrips sells for about $30; 30 GoSmile ampules retail for around $75 (plus you'll want the stylish travel compact, which comes with seven ampules and costs $45).
 Of course, GoSmile is easier than strips to use in ''maintenance'' situations, like just after a debauched teeth-staining episode. It might be better in the long run just to knock off the red wine and cigarettes at lunch, but why worry about the long run when you can just obliterate the evidence (or at least feel as if you have) before your afternoon staff meeting? Collier Strong, a Los Angeles makeup artist who gives GoSmile to various famous clients and says he uses the stuff twice a day himself, argues that everyone's standards are changing. ''Now public awareness has risen to the point where if you don't have nice teeth, people look at you and ask themselves, at least, why not? There's so many products, it's so easy to have a beautiful smile now. It's like somebody who doesn't have call waiting,'' he says, with a jovial laugh. ''How primitive! Come on, do you have electricity?'' This shift has shown up lately in a culturewide makeover mania, with reality shows like ''The Swan'' peddling the dream of radical conversion from averageness to irresistibility as quickly as possible. 
 Actually, this urge may not be, like so much consumer behavior, totally irrational. Research dating back to the 1960's has shown the economic advantage of good looks. For example, better-looking people tend to earn more money than their plainer co-workers. One study examined attempts to use beauty products to ''ameliorate deficiencies in pulchritude,'' and found at least some payoff. And whatever the motive, there is another upside to dental vanity. When he started out, Levine says, ''people came to the dentist for health reasons. They were in pain. In the last five or six years, people come to the dentist, really, to enhance their smile. It's the No. 1 reason people go to the dentist.'' The result, he says, is that people probably take better care of their teeth now -- just as people who go to the gym in a quest for ripped abs can come out with healthier bodies. So even if mass vanity seems like a dark cloud, maybe it's one with a gleaming white lining.

LENGTH: 715 words

HEADLINE: How to End Grade Inflation

BYLINE: By Michael Berube. 
Michael Berube is the Paterno Family professor of literature at Pennsylvania State University.

 BODY:
Last month, Princeton University announced it would combat grade inflation by proposing that A-minuses, A's and A-pluses be awarded to no more than the top 35 percent of students in any course. For those of us in higher education, the news has come as a shock, almost as if Princeton had declared that spring in central New Jersey would begin promptly on March 21, with pleasant temperatures in the 60's and 70's through the end of the semester. For until now, grade inflation was like the weather: it got worse every year, or at least everyone said so, and yet hardly anybody did anything about it.
 There is nothing inherently wrong with grade inflation. Imagine a system of scoring on a scale from 1 to 6 in which everyone gets a 5 and above, or a scale of 1 to 10 in which the lowest posted score is around 8.5. Such are the worlds of figure skating and gymnastics. If colleges employed similar scoring systems, the class valedictorian would come in with a 4.0, followed closely by hundreds of students above 3.95, trailed by the class clown at 3.4. 
 Critics would argue that we must be perilously close to such a system right now. Several years ago, Harvard awarded ''honors'' to 90 percent of its graduates. For its part, Princeton has disclosed that A's have been given 47 percent of the time in recent years, up from 31 percent in the mid-1970's. Perhaps grade inflation is most severe at the most elite colleges, where everyone is so far above average that the rules of the Caucus Race in ''Alice in Wonderland'' apply: everybody has won, and all must have prizes. At the school where I teach, Penn State, grade inflation over the same period has not been nearly so drastic. In the spring semester of 1975, the average G.P.A. was 2.86; in 2001 it had risen to only 3.02. 
 Still, we don't grade all that toughly. English departments have basically worked on the A/B binary system for some time: A's and A-minuses for the best students, B's for everyone else and C's, D's and F's for students who miss half the classes or threaten their teachers with bodily harm. At Penn State, A's accounted for 47 percent of the grades in English in 2002. The numbers are similar for sociology, comparative literature and psychology -- and indeed for the College of Liberal Arts as a whole. The sciences and engineering, notoriously, are stingier. 
 What to do? If we so desired, we could recalibrate grades at Penn State, at Princeton or at any college in the country. The principle is simple enough, and it's crucial to every diving competition: we would merely need to account for each course's degree of difficulty.
 Every professor, and every department, produces an average grade -- an average for the professor over her career and an average for the discipline over the decades. And if colleges really wanted to clamp down on grade inflation, they could whisk it away statistically, simply by factoring those averages into each student's G.P.A. Imagine that G.P.A.'s were calculated on a scale of 10 with the average grade, be it a B-minus or an A-minus, counted as a 5. The B-plus in chemical engineering, where the average grade is, say, C-plus, would be rewarded accordingly and assigned a value of 8; the B-plus in psychology, where the average grade might be just over B-plus, would be graded like an easy dive, adequately executed, and given a 4.7.
 After all, colleges keep all the necessary statistics -- by year, by course and by department. We know perfectly well which courses require a forward somersault with two and a half twists from the pike position for an A, and which courses will give B's for cannonballs. We could even encourage professors and entire departments to increase their prestige by lowering their average grade and thereby increasing their ''degree of difficulty.'' Students who earn A's in difficult courses would benefit -- as would students who earn B's.
 Incorporating ''degree of difficulty'' into students' G.P.A.'s would turn campuses upside down; it would eliminate faculty capriciousness precisely by factoring it in; and it would involve nothing more than using the numbers we already have at our disposal. It would be confusing as hell. But it would yield a world in which the average grade was never anything more or less than the middle of the scale.

SECTION: Section 6; Column 2; Magazine Desk; Pg. 26; The Way We Live Now: 5-2-04: Phenomenon

LENGTH: 2968 words

HEADLINE: Exit Date

BYLINE: By Douglas McGray. 
Douglas McGray is a writer living in Washington.

 BODY:
On a snowy January evening, in the kitchen of a powder blue colonial at the end of a still, winding block in the suburbs of Washington, Titia and her husband, Kaprr, two immigrants from Sierra Leone, enjoyed a rare family evening together. Their youngest children, a giddy pair of elementary-schoolers, rushed in and out of the room. Their teenage daughter chattered about her ''cheerleading skills.'' Even the 17-year-old Deen made an appearance, slouching up from the basement to pick at leftovers from dinner. It seemed a storybook image of the American immigrant dream.
 But across the room, in low voices so the kids couldn't hear, Kaprr spoke about the circumstances threatening to break up his family. Kaprr and Titia have been living in the United States for 13 years. By the time they moved into this house five years ago, they had legal status, steady jobs, a growing family, night-school degrees well under way and a mortgage. Despite appearances, though, Kaprr and Titia are not Americans, or even on a certain path to citizenship. Rather, they are among at least 2,700 Sierra Leoneans living and working legally across the United States who face deportation unless they leave the country by May 3. 
 Kaprr and Titia settled in America as illegal immigrants after they overstayed their tourist visas, and Titia then tried and failed to win asylum. But they lucked into legal status in 1997, when the United States granted all Sierra Leoneans living within its borders something called temporary protected status, or T.P.S. On the books since the first Bush administration, T.P.S. was designed by Congress to shelter those who cannot benefit from refugee and asylum laws: foreign visitors staying in the United States on short-term visas or working illegally when their homeland suffers a humanitarian crisis. Recently, a vigorous lobby has urged the extension of temporary relief to Haitians, Colombians and Zimbabweans. 
 T.P.S. grants the right to work and live here legally, but provides no other perks of citizenship. At the end of a year, if a crisis persists, the government can offer another year of legal status; and at the end of that year, another, and so on. Of course, many crises, civil wars in particular, have a way of dragging on. Of the nine immigrant communities under T.P.S. protection, seven have been living year to year since 1997 or earlier; most of the 10,000 Liberians and 360 Somalis with temporary protected status have been legal residents since 1991, although the Liberians are most likely next up for deportation, and someday, the Somalis will have to follow.
 Kaprr first heard the rumors late last summer. Everyone in the Sierra Leonean community was talking about it: this would be the year T.P.S. ends, they said. Kaprr grew sick with worry. ''I couldn't think about anything else,'' he said. Under different circumstances, Kaprr and Titia might not mind this temporary life coming to a stop. Both of them miss Sierra Leone, even though the house they left was destroyed in the fighting, and their families were devastated -- Kaprr's parents and sister were killed, as was Titia's sister, and many others. Both of them want to return, eventually. But Titia's mother, who lives with the family, had a liver transplant last fall at Georgetown University Hospital; Kaprr and Titia pay for her health insurance. ''She's taking all these medications that we cannot afford if we go back,'' Titia said -- if the drugs are even available there. 
 And then there are the four thoroughly American kids. When, cautiously, Kaprr and Titia broached the topic of a possible move back to Sierra Leone, they were anxious and full of questions. ''They wanted to know about the electricity,'' Kaprr said, ''if there are going to be any medical facilities.'' Titia laughed. ''They wanted to know about the Cartoon Network. And do people have shoes? They asked: 'Do you sleep in trees?' '' When Titia and Kaprr brought home a series of documentaries about the war, their teenage daughter fled the room, terrified. The 8-, 11-, and 13-year-olds are all born American citizens; the 17-year-old is here on T.P.S. and eligible for deportation. ''If they have to go home. . . . '' Kaprr said, then paused. ''For them, it's not home.''
 The alternative, it seemed, was to stay illegally, until the kids finished school. But after so many years of legitimate American life, Kaprr did not want to live in hiding. ''We are law-abiding citizens,'' he said. Besides, the risk of sudden deportation seemed too great. All they would have to do is slip up at work, or run afoul of the law, and they could end up in detention. Their kids had never known such a fearful life and he didn't want to subject them to it now. (The family members have been identified in this article by their middle names.) 
 Like most Sierra Leoneans facing the likely end of their time in America, they could do little. They hoped the rumors were wrong and that T.P.S. would continue. They hoped they might qualify for a green card or that they would be recognized as good Americans and allowed to stay. They hoped for impossible things and tried not to think about those things too hard, so they could still take comfort in them. 
 One of Kaprr's night jobs had petitioned the Department of Labor to give him a permanent work visa, and his family a shot at permanent citizenship. But almost two years had passed since then, with no word. After hearing the rumors this summer, he feared he was running out of time.
One night late last summer, Titia came home from work with an idea, one they had never talked about before. She mentioned a woman from work, a nurse. She is a Sierra Leonean, Titia said. And an American citizen. And single. ''She is willing to marry you,'' Titia said. Just like that. Though Kaprr was shocked, he saw that the idea made a lot of sense. His marriage to Titia was not officially recorded in the United States. Marrying another woman seemed like their only option. Because Titia had applied for asylum, and failed, she was scheduled for deportation as soon as T.P.S. ended. If she defied the deportation order, it was highly unlikely she would ever be able to return to the United States. But Kaprr's case was different, less urgent. Since he never applied for asylum, he had been merely an undocumented alien before T.P.S. took effect. Once T.P.S. ended, he would be undocumented again. If the kids were going to stay in Virginia with at least one of their parents, Kaprr would have to find a way to stay in Virginia, too. 
 After two weeks of deliberation, they agreed to go ahead. Titia arranged for Kaprr to meet his future wife after work, and came along, as matchmaker. It was brief and businesslike. When I asked him about it, Kaprr simply shrugged at the memory. 
 Kaprr and the American married shortly after, on paper at least. But just a few weeks later, Kaprr received an unexpected round of good news: his petition for a permanent work visa had been approved. After 13 years in the United States, he was finally on a path to citizenship -- and entangled now in a bureaucratic soap opera. He could not petition for Titia to stay with him in America, as his wife, because technically, he was married to someone else. As he explained the cruelty of the situation, he shook his head and forced a wry, stoic smile, even as his eyes began to redden. 
 The rumors about T.P.S. turned out to be true. The very week Kaprr got his work authorization, the Department of Homeland Security gave Sierra Leoneans eight months to sell their belongings, book flights home and leave the country for good. When T.P.S. ends, most of the Sierra Leoneans will most likely try to stay on illegally, rather than return to one of the poorest countries in the world. Alimamy Sesay, a Sierra Leonean community organizer and caseworker outside Washington, guesses that ''probably 90 percent'' will ignore the deportation order. This winter, I spoke with at least two dozen Sierra Leoneans who were here under T.P.S., and not one of them was planning to leave in May. Many hoped to win some kind of last-minute reprieve. Failing that, they will stay on anyway, because they have built lives here and raised families here, or because the money they earn supports a family back in Sierra Leone.
 Once all of Kaprr's paperwork goes through (including, now, a pending divorce), and he scrapes together a few thousand dollars in fees, he and his kids will remain in their powder blue colonial at the end of the block. In a couple of years, Kaprr's lawyer tells him, he will probably be able to bring Titia back from Sierra Leone, though he figures with the Department of Homeland Security's backlog of immigration cases, and his own fragile citizenship status, it could be longer. That makes them among the lucky ones. It just doesn't feel like it.
It was raining that day back in 1991 when Kaprr placed one small suitcase in the trunk of an uncle's car and crossed the river to the Freetown airport. His young wife, Titia, was already in America. This was Feb. 28, Kaprr said, the last day he spent in his country -- and just before the rebel leader Foday Sankoh crossed the border from Liberia at the head of a brutal militia.
 Kaprr figured he and Titia would be back soon, maybe after a few years. He had a decent job in Freetown, but he longed to open his own accounting firm. The Sierra Leoneans who visited from America seemed so rich, he said, with their new clothes and their wallets filled with dollars. In the U.S.A., he thought, he could make some money in a hurry, get an accounting degree, then return home.
 He found a job as a nursing assistant, just as Titia had done, and enrolled in a vocational tech program. He figured he would soon be able to get a good enough job to start saving some money and taking accounting classes at night. Instead, he and Titia had to make a choice between paying his tuition and their mounting bills. He dropped out of the tech training, so he would have more hours to work. It was so frustrating, he said. He felt as if he was already giving up on his American dream.
 Soon enough, though, the young couple had greater worries. Machete-wielding rebels battled Sierra Leonean forces as the conflict back home worsened. The army, meanwhile, staged a coup, tossing Sierra Leone's elected president out of office and installing a military regime. Deportation was always a risk, but now, Kaprr and Titia worried, what would they return to? They decided it might be a good idea to wait the insurgency out. 
 Neither of them could make a particularly strong case for asylum, since asylum seekers have to prove they have fled targeted political or religious persecution, and civil war -- ''generalized violence,'' the law sometimes calls it -- tends not to discriminate in its victims. But Titia's family, at least, was politically active in the past. So she applied, and gained tentative legal status during the two years of immigration court proceedings and three years of appeals that followed. Kaprr kept working, quietly, as a nurse's assistant, hoping he could hitch his fate to hers.
 When Kaprr and Titia became legal immigrants under T.P.S., life got better, or at least more secure. The couple no longer lived in constant fear that immigration authorities would expel them to a country ravaged by war. But neither of them was able to use newly achieved legal status to establish a stable career -- a common difficulty with temporary protection.
 Until his recent layoff, Kaprr had a contract gig as a network engineer with a well-known technology company. At night, he takes accounting classes at a local university, balances books for a few small businesses and prepares tax returns. And from Friday night through Sunday he lives and works at a group home for mentally disabled adults. When Titia and I visited the home, a half-dozen of Kaprr's charges sat apart from each other in secondhand couches and chairs, some of them reading, others just staring. A loud symphony played from a radio in the dimly lighted living room. Only an orange and white cat moved, curling and uncurling its tail as it stepped from one lap to the next. 
 ''One job is not enough to support a family in this country,'' Kaprr said. Titia nodded in agreement. She starts her first shift as a nursing assistant at 11 at night, she said, and works until 7 in the morning. She has an hour off to drive to her next nursing assistant job, where she works from 8 in the morning until 4 in the afternoon. By the time she goes shopping and makes dinner for the kids, she has time for only a couple hours of sleep. ''You work all night, you drive around all day,'' she said. ''Sometimes I'll just sit there, like a zombie. But you can't; you have to think about the things that need to be done.'' 
 Even working papers constitute a hardship for legal immigrants. The year-to-year paperwork Kaprr and Titia bring to prospective employers shows an expiration date usually just a few months away. That keeps them in the same low-wage jobs they had when they first came to the country. Titia did put herself through nursing school by cutting back her hours a few months at a time and moving her shifts around. Once she passes a state exam, she'll qualify to be a nurse, which will allow her to make more money and cut back to 40-hour weeks. Still, she said, ''even if I got my license, I would probably stay working as a nurse's assistant.'' Temporary citizenship means temporary work.
 ''T.P.S. is the bare minimum,'' explained Bill Frelick of Amnesty International. ''It is intended to segregate you legally and socially and economically so you don't immigrate, so you're more likely to go home when the designation has expired.'' 
'I understand the difficulty involved when people put down roots,'' a staff member of the Department of Homeland Security told me. ''That's one of the consequences of T.P.S., one of the things that just happens. But this program's just not designed for that.''
 On this point, critics agree. They think T.P.S. is a valuable fix for temporary crises, but unreasonable when it goes on too long. For the last seven years, Senator Jack Reed, a Rhode Island Democrat, has tried in vain to legislate a reprieve for the most drastically affected, Liberian immigrants, many of whom settled in Rhode Island and have lived year to year since 1991. To Reed's mind, the Liberians in his state became permanent a long time ago, regardless of their official status. ''They've established a place in the community,'' Reed says. ''They have children who've been born here. With each passing day, the case gets stronger.''
 The problem isn't unique to Liberians, Reed explains, or to Sierra Leoneans. It is intrinsic to temporary protected status. ''It works pretty well, if there's a brief interlude of instability,'' he says. ''We should be thinking about a system that recognizes when it's no longer temporary. Ten years is not temporary. We can develop a system where at least there's a presumption that after so many years, you can become a citizen. And we can do that on a general basis, not a country-by-country basis. There are ways to do it.'' In fact, there was talk at the White House toward the end of the Clinton administration about creating a path from temporary protection to permanent-resident status, one State Department official reports. ''Then the administration changed, and we were back to square one,'' he says. 
 Thousands here on T.P.S. hold out hope that Congress might include them in an amnesty program for undocumented immigrants. President Bush has urged immigration reform. A series of bills working through Congress could grant legal residency and a chance at citizenship to longtime illegal residents; these bills may benefit longtime legal residents as well. No immigration reform bill is likely to pass before next year, though, which means Sierra Leoneans with T.P.S., and possibly Liberians as well, would not be spared deportation. Advocates like Sesay have lobbied the White House to grant Sierra Leoneans a onetime extension of a year or two, called deferred enforced departure. That would give Congress the option to include them in any immigration reform law that passes next year; at the very least, Sesay argues, it would give families time to save money and plan for the move home, or finish professional degrees. But Sesay reports little headway.
 As thousands of Sierra Leoneans across the country consider their futures, uncomplicated circumstances seem to be the exception. One man I met at a local community meeting, a soft-spoken engineer with two master's degrees and his own home in suburban Maryland, told me he would probably stay, taking an illegal job and dodging immigration authorities, so his 8-year-old American-born son, who has severe cerebral palsy, can continue with his special-education classes. Back in Sierra Leone, he said, the schools would have no use for his son; simply getting around in a motorized wheelchair would be nearly impossible. Another man told me he may stay illegally to support his elderly mother, who recently won asylum from the grim refugee camps in Guinea, where many Sierra Leoneans fled. She arrived in the United States, alone, less than a month before T.P.S. was due to expire.
 When I talked with Kaprr and Titia's teenage daughter, I asked her if she'd ever thought about living in Africa. ''There are snakes,'' she said, screwing up her nose. ''I don't like snakes.'' She has no idea that she narrowly avoided leaving the United States -- nor did she realize the choices her parents had already made to keep her here. She sensed something was up, though. She knew her parents were worried. ''If they're just by themselves, I go up and eavesdrop,'' she said. ''They really want to go back. Just not right now.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Temporary American: After 13 years in the United States, Titia must leave. (Photograph by Claudio Vazquez)

HEADLINE: Lost, and Found, in Riga

BYLINE: By KATHERINE ZOEPF. 
KATHERINE ZOEPF is a graduate student at the London School of Economics.

 BODY:
FOR the past several months, the tabloid press in London, where I live, has been making wild predictions about the hordes of hopeful migrants who can be expected to descend on Britain now that the European Union is expanding. 
 Among the new entrants is Latvia, so when I began planning a trip there in mid-April and visited the Air Baltic Web site (www.airbaltic.com), I was amused to be greeted by a large picture of a buxom Slavic blonde in a Union Jack bikini. The photograph was advertising ultralow, one-way-only fares to London from the Baltic states.
 But if citizens of the Baltic countries are eager to get better acquainted with Western Europe, Latvia seems just as eager to greet visitors from abroad. The nation's flag was first raised at NATO headquarters in Brussels on April 2, followed by formal accession to the European Union this month. During three days in Latvia's capital, Riga, I found the feeling of change and excitement palpable. There was little of the characteristic Latvian reticence. Instead, I was eagerly asked what had brought me to Latvia, what Americans thought about the country, and even what I had thought of last year's Eurovision Song Contest, held in Riga, which remains the high water mark for the city's nascent tourism industry. Prices in Riga, too, seem to be rapidly approaching Western European standards. 
 A modest, clean hotel in or near the old city costs about $100 for a double room. Riga has an exciting, and very international, restaurant scene (everything from Georgian to Ukrainian to Uzbek cuisine), and visitors so inclined can plow their way through mounds of Baltic caviar in elegant surroundings. But a budget traveler could eat heartily for around $5 a day, simply by sticking to the many cafeteria-style establishments. In short, Western-style comforts are readily available, but the real reason to go to Riga now is to watch a beautiful old city energetically reinventing itself.
 I arrived at Riga's sparkling, small hassle-free airport late on a Friday evening, too tired to contemplate much exploring that night. The taxi trip into the city center took less than 15 minutes, whisking down a short strip of highway and across one of the Daugava River bridges, from which I could see the floodlit face of Riga Castle. Soon, I was settling into my airy room at the Elizabetesnams, a snug hotel in Riga's Jugendstil, or Art Nouveau, neighborhood. The next morning, after plates of dried-apple salad, an omelet, dense brown bread and Latvian cheeses in the hotel's sunny breakfast room, I set out to see the city, now a metropolis of over 750,000. The streets were filled with the kind of cold, harsh Nordic sunlight that can give you a headache if you're not used to it. At first, the stark patches of light and shadow made the city feel otherworldly, a bit like a film set.
 At the Russian Orthodox Cathedral, two old women with thick shawls knotted under their chins were selling bunches of snowdrops. In a square just off Kalku Iela, one of the main streets running through Riga's Old City, a small skating rink had been set up, and children skated to a tinny rendition of ''Material Girl.''
 Riga is said to have one of the finest collections of Art Nouveau buildings anywhere and, turning onto Alberta Iela, that afternoon, I could easily believe it. An architecture buff could happily spend a couple of hours here, just working her way around the block. Riga was spared the bombings that destroyed so many of Germany's Art Nouveau buildings. Whole neighborhoods look much as they must have looked before 1914, when Riga was a prosperous seafaring city with a large shipyards and a thriving merchant class. Many of the elaborate, fanciful structures were designed by Mikhail Eisenstein, whose son Sergei became one of Russia's best-known film directors.
 It was impossible not to smile at, say, the grumpy-looking stone dragons flanking the doorway at 8 Antonijas Iela, or the sphinxes at 2A Alberta Iela. At 33 Elizabetes Iela, stone men with bare torsos and furrowed brows strain with every fiber to lift the columns that hold up the third and fourth floors, while the nymphs on the third floor support their balconies with careless ease.
 After a stop at a local sweet shop, Staburadze, for lingonberries preserved in powdered sugar, I headed down to the river again. From the spire of St. Peter's, a 13th-century church that was subjected to a slightly clumsy renovation under the Soviets, I could see all the way down the Daugava (in early April, still studded with a few chunks of floating ice) to the Gulf of Riga. Looking down at the sea of red-tiled and green tin roofs surrounding the church, I could see how the city had grown up, with the very oldest buildings clustered by the river, ringed by graceful Art Nouveau houses, and finally grim Soviet-era suburbs beyond.
 It seemed time for a more thorough Latvian history lesson, at the Occupation Museum, which is near the river in a huge rectangular bunker of a building. The story told on its walls is unabashedly nationalistic, beginning with Latvia's little window of independence between the two world wars, cut tragically short by successive annexation and conquest by the Soviet Union, the Nazis, and the Soviets again. A large map near the entrance shows the network of Soviet prison camps where Latvian patriots were often sent: many of the camp sites are above the Arctic Circle, and an information card notes laconically that prisoners were permitted to stop working outdoors when temperatures dropped lower than 42 degrees below zero. 
 One particularly moving exhibit displays everyday items from the camps -- felt boots, homemade scissors, bits of blanket -- accompanied by texts written by former Latvian political prisoners. Typical was this passage by Martins Bisters, a survivor who described an empty oil barrel that had served the inmates as a latrine: ''We stank from unbelievable filthiness, which was worse than anything else done to us. And still we Latvians retained our humanity in order to survive all humiliation and proudly return home to Latvia.'' 
 By the time I left the Occupation Museum, Nostalija, billed as a ''retro Soviet restaurant,'' which had caught my eye earlier in the day, no longer seemed appealing.
 Instead, I decided to try Dzirnavas, part of the Lido chain of ''traditional'' Latvian restaurants. For more than a decade, the Lido group has been wooing Latvian urbanites with a pleasantly romanticized version of the country's rural past. At Dzirnavas, waitresses wore puff-sleeved traditional dresses, families sat at rough-hewn trestle tables, and the whole place pulsed with rollicking Latvian folk music.
 The food -- bacon-and-tomato-scented solanka soup, pancakes stuffed with a salty cheese and dill mixture -- was delicious, but I was more intrigued by a pamphlet on my table, telling the Dzirnavas story. ''Have you ever been in a tavern of a good old Latvian miller?'' it began. ''Lido Dzirnavas -- revived good old days in the heart of modern Riga.''
 Surely no one in the restaurant had ever even met a ''good old Latvian miller.'' But after 50 years of enforced Sovietization, perhaps this sort of cheerful reinvention of Latvian heritage was a healthy sign.
 The next morning, I decided to visit the Ethnographic Open-Air Museum, a collection of 18th- and 19th-century buildings near Lake Jugla, about 40 minutes by car from central Riga. It is situated on about 250 acres of pine forest, through which visitors could roam freely.
 When I asked Ernests, the Elizabetesnams' friendly manager, about the museum, he assured me that it was a must-see, the perfect place to learn about ''the real Latvian life.'' He printed a bus map and schedule for me from his computer and pointed out the stop -- across the street from the Russian Orthodox Cathedral -- where I should wait.
 I found the bus stop soon enough, but the vehicle rumbling towards me, clearly marked No. 1, was a trolley instead of a bus. Ernests' English was fairly fluent, but I wondered if he could possibly have gotten the word wrong. Or perhaps Riga's trolleys and buses were all part of the same system? Ernests had said that there was a full half-hour between buses, so I didn't like to risk missing one. I decided to hop on. After all, if it turned out to be the wrong vehicle, I could simply hop off again and only be out about 35 cents for my mistake. 
 When the conductor came by my seat to take my fare, I showed her my map, and gingerly tested out the Latvian phrase that Ernests had taught me: ''I'd like to go to this museum, please.'' 
 The conductor seemed puzzled and then, as she read my map, concerned. A torrent of Latvian issued forth. I had clearly made a mistake. I got up and, smiling sheepishly and excusing myself in crude Russian, tried to make my way to the door of the trolley. No problem, thank you, I tried to convey, but I would simply get off at the next stop. 
 The conductor, an older woman in a blue smock, wouldn't hear of it. She gripped my arm and motioned me back into my seat. To my deepening embarrassment, she began making her way around the trolley, asking the other passengers if they spoke any English.
 We seemed to be heading east, outside the zone my map covered. At the next stop, the conductor, the driver, and several passengers got off, pulling me with them, and huddled on the sidewalk to peer at my map.
 Finally, one of the other passengers seemed to nominate herself as my guardian. She introduced herself as Anna, and beckoned me into her nearby apartment building. Anna's neighbor, Vesma, had studied some English, and seemed strangely delighted to have her Sunday dinner preparations interrupted by a mortified, lost American.
 ANNA and Vesma's building was a dingy Soviet-era apartment house. But inside it was very cozy, the stairwells choked with bicycles and smelling strongly of roasted meat, and the neighbors dropping in on each other with easy friendliness. Vesma's apartment consisted of a single, small room and adjoining kitchen nook. Everything was exquisitely neat; the family's beds converted by day into sofas and chairs. The floor was covered with worn, overlapping Oriental rugs, and intricately painted Easter eggs hung from pussy willows in vases.
 Soon Vesma, Anna and I were sitting in her tiny kitchen, drinking coffee and munching rosewater-flavored Lithuanian chocolates. Thanks to Vesma's skill as an interpreter, the three-way conversation gradually became less awkward. We talked about Anna and Vesma's children, about the ways Riga is changing, about the Victorian children's books that Vesma likes to read to practice her English.
 I did eventually make it to the Ethnographic Open-Air Museum, where I spent two hours examining old-fashioned churches and fishermen's cottages, and watching crafts demonstrations. As lovely and original as it all was, I can't agree with Ernests that it was the best way to learn about ''the real Latvian life.'' My happily misbegotten bus ride accomplished that. 

The bottom line
 I spent 47.77 lat (about $90) a day on transportation, food, lodging and activities during three days and nights in Riga. Though Latvia is entering the European Union, it is not expected to adopt the euro for another couple of years. Prices are calculated at 0.556 lat to the dollar. The official language is Latvian, though Russian and, to a lesser extent, English are widely understood. 

Lodging
 At the Elizabetesnams Hotel, 27 Elizabetes Iela, (371) 7509292, fax(371) 7509291, on the Internet at www.elizabetesnams.lv, a large single room cost about $85 a night, with an elaborate hot breakfast. 
 The Hotel Valdemars, 23 Kr. Valdemara Iela, (371) 7334462 or (371) 7332132, fax (371) 7333001, on the Web at www.valdemars.lv, is in an Art Nouveau building; its interior is more modest. A smallish single room with bath cost $47, with breakfast. 

Food
 Dzirnavas, at 74-76 Dzirnavu Iela, (371) 728-6204), serves a smorgasbord of Latvian specialties. A hearty dinner of solanka soup, pork meatballs, creamed vegetables, savory pancakes and mineral water came to $6.
 Pelmeni XL, at 7 Kalku Iela, specializes in chewy steamed dumplings with a variety of fillings and toppings, all sold by weight. Apple tea and a large bowl of cabbage dumplings with grated cheese were $1.15.
 Sievasmates Piradzini (Mother-in-Law's Pirogi) at 10 Kalku Iela is a bustling little place, where customers pluck pirogi buns -- filled with anything from poppy seeds to bacon to dried apricots -- from an array of steaming trays, cafeteria-style. A cup of tea and sweet pirogi stuffed with cheese and jam was $1.70.

Things to Do
 The Occupation Museum, 1 Strelnieku Laukums, (371) 7212715, www.occupationmuseum.lv, is free, though donations are encouraged.
 A ticket to a Saturday afternoon concert at the Riga Dome Cathedral, 1 Doma Laukums, (371) 7213498, cost $9.40.
 Admission to the Ethnographic Open-Air Museum, 440 Brivibas Gatve, (371) 7994515 costs $1.85. KATHERINE ZOEPF

LENGTH: 167 words

HEADLINE: PRINCETON LIMITS A'S

BYLINE: By Robert Strauss

 BODY:
The Princeton University faculty has overwhelmingly approved a new grading system intended to stem grade inflation. The proposal by the undergraduate dean, Nancy Malkiel, limits the number of A's, including A-pluses and A-minuses, given in any undergraduate department to 35 percent of students for all courses and 55 percent for those taking upper-level independent work. 
It takes effect next fall. A study of the Princeton class of 2002 showed that 65 percent of students graduated with an average of B-plus or higher and that a student with a B average would rank 923 out of a class of 1,079. Students had voiced concerns during debate over the proposal that limiting A's would unfairly jeopardize them in job and graduate-school applications, since it would lower their grade-point averages relative to other colleges that did not limit A's. Dr. Malkiel stressed that the new guidelines were ''expectations,'' not strict limits, and that specific cases will be viewed on their merits. Robert Strauss

SECTION: Section 6; PT2; Column 1; Sophisticated Traveler Magazine; Pg. 75; CELEBRATION

LENGTH: 2021 words

HEADLINE: New Orleans

BYLINE: By Frederick Turner. 
Frederick Turner's new book,''In the Land of Temple Caves'' (Counterpoint), is a meditation on art and the human spirit.

 BODY:

New Orleans is a town of nicknames: the City of Sin, the City That Care Forgot, the Big Easy. Waiting for a bus on Basin Street, I asked a woman if New Orleans's good-time reputation was deserved. ''If you got five people waitin' in line,'' she smiled, ''you likely to have a party.''

The Mood
 At 8:30 on a Saturday morning I was awakened in my hotel room by the long, one-note wail of a boat horn. Normally, I can't sleep so late, but this was New Orleans, and I'd been out well past midnight listening to music. Pulling back the curtains, I looked out on the great river and a 200-foot-long barge sliding past Algiers Point, the water rough and taupe-hued under a gray winter sky.
 For many years I'd been coming down here, drawn by the music and the food -- both very rich. But in this morning moment it was suddenly borne in upon me that neither of these civic treasures sets the tone of this town the way the powerful presence of the river does. The Mississippi made New Orleans a tourist destination as far back as the early 19th century, and then it made it into the nation's busiest port. A huge dam above Baton Rouge now chains the river to its current channel so that it won't seek a shortcut to the Gulf of Mexico and leave the city a sea of mud and desolation. Chatting with a cabby about the river, I asked him what New Orleans would be like without it. Daniel Thompson had spent 40 years on the Mississippi. Now he watched for a break in traffic, then eased through it. ''Wouldn't,'' was all he answered.
 Until the 1984 World's Fair the New Orleans waterfront was about as inviting as that of Bayonne, N.J. But a sizable stretch of it was razed and renovated for that forgettable event so that now from the French Market on Decatur to the Crescent City Connection Bridge across to Algiers, it's possible for visitors to get a sense of how the river continues to shape what the city is. Here, set down beside a flow so mighty you don't really see it, are extravagant attractions chorusing their debt to the Mississippi: Margaritaville, the Jackson Brewery mall, the Moonwalk promenade, Woldenberg Riverfront Park, the aquarium, the convention center, the casino, cruise ships, riverboats.
 And if you were to pass beyond all this to where a grittier kind of commerce commences, you would find vestiges of a riverfront town substantially unchanged in a century and a half: long, warping warehouses where the corrugated tin peels away from the structures' sides; splintered docks on battered pilings; railroad sidings with trains of boxcars many blocks long; abandoned factories with immense chimneys. Even these chimneys add to the overwhelming impression of the river's shaping omnipotence, simply because in their immensity they are fully in keeping with the scale of everything else down here -- the bridge, the barges, the cruise ships: it's all immense, as it must be to match the Mississippi.
 But until summoned by that boat horn I had never understood much of this. Instead, I had long believed that traditional jazz was the tone-setter for the city. Now I think that jazz isn't the emotional equal of the river; I don't think it's the equal either of another tradition long preceding it: necromancy. New Orleans has a historic love affair with death. Of no other American city can this be said. There is a whiff of the grave hanging over the place, something musty, decayed. Many have felt this, but it forcefully came to me on my recent visit when I was walking St. Peter Street from Basin into what local people call the Quarter. I passed a tall, spare house whose door, close-set columns and pediment struck me as the entrance to a crypt, not a home: sooty, settling, scrunched like the age-blackened face of the mummy I'd just seen at an exhibit on Egyptian funeral customs at the New Orleans Museum of Art.
 Here is a city whose older cemeteries remain prime tourist attractions even though they are now very dangerous places to enter. You can get a vampire tour of New Orleans, buy goofer dust (dirt dug from a grave) at many a tourist shop, visit a voodoo museum. Yes, all these are transparently touristy. But all of them reach roots into authentic cultural soil, and as New Orleans itself is raised a precarious few inches above the river's wet suck, so the city's hectic gaiety seems raised above the reaching arms of death. What other place makes a brassy party out of a funeral?

The Food
 New Orleans, it is frequently observed, is a gumbo of a town, a useful shorthand reference to its mix of French, Spanish, African and Caribbean influences as well as to its single most characteristic dish. A bowl of gumbo, with its okra and oysters, its shrimp and sassafras, its spicy, peppery finish, has defined what made New Orleans cuisine unique as far back as memory takes us. But even in this city that clings to tradition, cultural evolution is at work. Gumbo may still define the cuisine, but the grand old restaurants that proudly served it and have so long stood for New Orleans cooking seemed, with one exception, very weary to me when I ate at some of them last spring.
 So when I came back this winter I made it a point to investigate restaurants that had grown up and flourished since I first came down here believing that eating in New Orleans meant dinner at Antoine's. What I discovered dining at Bayona, Stella!, Restaurant August, Peristyle and the Bistro at the Maison de Ville will surprise no one who has been keeping up with the local restaurant scene: this remains a fabulous eating town, right up there with New York and San Francisco and maybe superior to either because of the distinctive nature of the indigenous cuisine.
 The one exception to my disappointment with the old-timers was Commander's Palace, still run by the Brennan family according to their exacting standards. I planned on having their famous pompano, but the chef, Tory McPhail, said they'd had it on the menu the night before and recommended the speckled trout. When I tasted it (beautifully balanced between flaky and moist) I was glad the pompano hadn't been available. I had the gumbo du jour as well, and every mouthful reminded me of why I have so long loved New Orleans cooking.
 The Brennans, of course, have been around a long time. The current star on the scene is the chef-owner Susan Spicer, who founded Bayona in 1990 and most recently co-founded Cobalt in 2001. When I dined at Bayona I understood what all the fuss is about. This is a softly stunning spot of salmon-colored walls, mirrors and big bouquets. Spicer described herself to me as a Navy brat whose father had retired here. ''Luckily enough for me,'' she smiled, ''he picked a great food town.'' I told her I was leaning toward the buttermilk-fried rabbit in a Creole mustard sauce. She approved of that inclination, adding that she'd been buying rabbit from the same man for several years because his product was so consistently excellent. That kind of reliance on local producers and attention to detail was evident in everything I tasted at Bayona down through dessert. Rabbit-in-mustard is one of my favorite dishes but a good deal more tricky to prepare well than it would appear. Spicer's version was tender enough to cut easily with a fork and compared favorably with any I recall from my favorite Parisian bistros.
 I had a good dinner at Stella!, and ate even better at Restaurant August and Peristyle. I also found room for three splendid lunches at the Bistro at the Maison de Ville, where Patrick Van Hoorebeek, the city's master of culinary ceremonies, presides as maitre d'hotel. When I came in out of a rainy Monday there were only three tables occupied. At one were the owners of the long-famed Galatoire's; at another were the owners of Alex Patout's Louisiana Kitchen. And as if that hadn't been enough to tell me all I needed to know about the Bistro's food and service, Patrick gave me a lagniappe of an anecdote as I staggered out after consuming a marvelous cassoulet. ''When Albert Finney was here years ago filming 'Miller's Crossing' he took to coming in here regularly,'' Patrick said. '' 'Patrick,' he said to me one night, 'this restaurant is an island of sanity in a sea of madness.' '' We are, you see, but one building removed from Bourbon Street!'' (America's answer to 18th-century London's Gin Lane).

The Style
 If the river and the underworld of necromancy establish the mood of this town, then jazz, broadly construed, defines its style: swaggering, swinging, sexy. It is the single most important item in the city's promotional kit. Jazz images hit you the moment you exit from your plane, and its sounds may be heard in the Quarter from midmorning on, when enterprising trumpeters and tenormen set up on street corners. But traditional jazz is fading away in the city of its birth, outmuscled by urban blues, R & B, funk and rock -- none of which, of course, could exist without jazz.
 When I first visited here in 1961, Preservation Hall on St. Peter was newly established, a place where long-neglected black musicians could find work playing the old way. The clubs around the corner on Bourbon played breakneck Dixieland, and in the Quarter there were two or three blues spots. Preservation Hall still marches on before packed houses, and there is plenty of electric blues to be heard. But jazz of any sort has pretty much left Bourbon.
 The singer and banjo player Banu Gibson has played with traditional groups here since 1981, and when I asked her whether that style was dying out she said: ''Well, there's just so much other stuff out there now. We've lost most of our traditional jazz clubs. Partly, that's just the evolution of taste, but part of it is economics. If a club owner can get four electric players with speakers and so on, why would he want to pay for seven acoustical ones? And, really, you can't get that full, traditional sound with anything less than a sextet.'' Gibson now finds herself in greater demand in places like St. Louis. ''But don't get me wrong,'' she hastened to add, ''this town is still deep in great jazz players. Go by the Spotted Cat while you're here and catch the Jazz Vipers. They do great versions of 30's numbers.''
 Gibson was right to send me to the Spotted Cat in the currently happening Faubourg Marigny. The New Orleans Jazz Vipers were a well-rehearsed sextet featuring violin and the rarely heard bass sax. But, after all, the evening had a certain staidness to it, both in the charts the band played and in the demeanor of the all-white, determinedly middle-aged audience.
 The real action was elsewhere, and it wasn't jazz. It was rock with the local legends, the Radiators, at Tipitina's in the gritty warehouse and wharf district; blues with Yvonne Williams and the Juke Joint Players at the Lounge Lizards on Decatur; funk with Funk'n Horns at Donna's Bar and Grill on North Rampart across from Louis Armstrong Park.
 Particularly the action was with the Radiators, playing before a packed house and with an additional line of petitioners waiting outside in a pelting rain. When the band struck up about 10:30, the instant voltage in the room was astonishing. I found myself next to a comely youngish woman down from Baton Rouge. ''There was no question where I would be tonight!'' she shouted. ''I left the baby with Mama -- and here I am!''
 At Donna's I found Funk'n Horns to be a hard-hitting unit that just blew hell out of every 20-minute number they played. The drummer was white, but the rest of the players were lean, young black men. To a listener with a historical cast of mind there was something deeply moving in the fact that their jazz-inflected playing was happening on the very ground of the vanished Storyville district where so many of the early jazz greats got their start. Here, I felt, was authentic continuity in a city that prizes it.
 The happiest face in the room belonged to Donna's husband, Charlie, who was working behind the bar and was clearly proud of the young men up on the stage. ''All these boys,'' he said, nodding in their direction, ''I been knowin' them since they was 15, 16 years old. 
 And now look at them go!''
