SECTION: Section 14WC; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk; Pg. 8; Looking Through a Lens/BETSY BRAUN LANE

LENGTH: 950 words

HEADLINE: A Freedom Path, by Way of Peekskill

BYLINE: By SUSAN HODARA

 BODY:
THE photographer Betsy Braun Lane has been spending little time behind her camera lately. Instead, she has been searching local libraries and historical archives for records and other sources verifying what until now has been predominantly oral history.
 It is all part of her effort to create an exhibition of photographs exploring the history of the Underground Railroad in Peekskill, for which she received the 2004 Arts Alive Artist Grant from the Westchester Arts Council/New York State Council on the Arts.
 What she is unearthing -- not only about the Underground Railroad but about African-Americans in Peekskill in the 1700's and 1800's -- is reshaping her conception of the photographic work that will follow, in an exhibition scheduled to open in October entitled ''Choosing Freedom: Following the Spirit of the Underground Railroad.'' 
 Ms. Braun Lane, 57, began working in photography 10 years ago after a circuitous journey that started with the study of painting and a college degree in history, followed by careers as a middle school history teacher, a substance-abuse counselor and an actress and model. Since 2002, her photography has been exhibited in 18 solo, group and juried shows throughout the area. 
 A Westchester resident for 25 years, Ms. Braun Lane, who was raised in New Jersey and is the mother of two grown daughters, lives in a 230-year-old farmhouse in Ossining with her husband, Whitney Lane, a studio photographer. She spoke recently about photography and the research she is doing for her coming show. 

Q. What elements of photography captivate you?

A. I'm in love with available light and fascinated by the passage of time. I'm not a photojournalist, nor do I manipulate my subjects. Instead, I try to capture the spirit of a place by finding the moment and shooting what has been left behind.

Q. Discuss your attraction to contemporary ruins.

A. As an historian, I have an interest in archaeology and architecture as tangible remnants of our past. I am also fascinated by what ruins represent about our intentions. Ruins occur because something happens to our process; our purposes come to an end, but the buildings still stand. But the courses of nature don't stop. Eventually the elements take over, and what remains is what has become of that initial purpose.

Q. What led to this project?

A. I followed newspaper articles about the Museum of the Underground Railroad project in Peekskill. The former mayor, Fran Gibbs, introduced me to its founders, Waymond Brothers and his wife, LaFern Joseph. They have led tours of Underground Railroad sites in Peekskill for several years, in association with the National Parks Service. I became fascinated by this piece of unexplored history.
 I am also a descendant of the Mandevilles, who settled in Peekskill before the Revolutionary War and operated the Mandeville Tavern there. 
 In 2002 I shot a series of photographs of the abandoned Anaconda Wire and Cable Company factory in Hastings-on-Hudson that I called ''Reflecting Reality.'' I imagined that same aesthetic informing a photographic series of Underground Railroad sites; I thought I'd be going into old spaces and uncovering the story of that period. In fact, while the locations have been accurately identified, often the structures there have been destroyed or reconstructed. 
 My objective, then, was to relate the present Peekskill population to families of the past, but when I began researching, there was a lack of specific documentation about the Underground Railroad and the people who supported it. 

Q. What are you uncovering in your research?

A. The Underground Railroad was a network of ''conductors'' -- church people, freemen, abolitionists -- who helped slaves escape to Canada before and during the Civil War. Part of its route ran through the Peekskill area. I started my research to find these places, but to do that, I had to know the people, and I discovered a dearth of knowledge about them. There is a valid oral history, and there are passing references in old newspapers and deeds, but there is no written history specifically concerning the origination and development of the African-American population here.
 Nor have I found church records, marriage certificates or pictures of church functions or community celebrations. So not only am I verifying the existence of the Underground Railroad in Peekskill, but I also am exploring the community during that time. 
 It's the information that's missing that's so compelling. And it is to be celebrated. The Underground Railroad was the first cooperative multicultural effort in our new country. It existed solely for a humanitarian purpose and conflicted directly with the laws and economic stability of many of these communities. My goal is the reconciliation of the information I uncover with the segments of the community it concerns -- to let these ''lost voices'' be heard. 

Q. How has the concept for your exhibition evolved as a result of your research?

A. I've had to open up my hand. I don't want to visualize yet what I'll be shooting; the work will be subject to how I conceptualize the findings of my research. Information is so hidden, under so many layers. I want viewers to experience the density I've confronted.

Q. How will your efforts benefit the local community?

A. There is a movement in Peekskill using the arts to stimulate the community, and I'm part of that. But unless an historical backdrop exists, that's only the icing on the cupcake. There has been an African-American community in Peekskill since the 1600's, and they have never had the chance to tell their story. My grant and the trust of the community are allowing me to create a fuller understanding of their history.

LENGTH: 3028 words

HEADLINE: Back Home, in Westchester

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER

 BODY:
CHARLIE MAYONE fondly remembers his childhood in Westchester County. As a boy, he recalls, he and his brother biked from Larchmont to the Croton Reservoir to fish, and later he proposed there to the woman who would become his wife, Jen. 
 Both were born and raised in the county, and it's where they chose to start their family. Then they left, first for Wilton, Conn., as their family grew and later to attractive retirement areas in Florida and then Maine.
 Now, having turned 74, they are coming back home, joining a tide of former Westchester residents who went away but are now returning in their old age. The reasons are many: the tug of home, relatives nearby, medical and other care in the New York region that is unrivaled almost anywhere. Also making it attractive is the fact that New York has one of the most expansive Medicaid programs in the country, reimbursing for services not covered in other states. 
 The returnees, many of them less healthy than the Mayones, are further stressing a system that is already struggling to meet the needs of an ever-growing number of the elderly requiring housing, transportation and other services that will help them remain independent in their later years.
 The Mayones are exchanging their home on three and a half acres in Cape Elizabeth, Me., for the security of a one-floor condominium in Somers, with family close by. Both are now healthy, but as they age they realize that in the future their health needs will require services like transportation, structured activities and medical care. While the warm memories and having a son and daughter-in-law nearby in Stamford were important factors in their decision, good care was also important, and especially the condos' proximity to My Second Home, an intergenerational day care center, which is only minutes away. 
 The Mayones are not alone in returning to Westchester for their later years. And this influx of returnees typically includes many of the frail elderly, who can no longer make it on their own, said Mae Carpenter, who heads the county's Department of Senior Programs and Services, and they may need extensive services, or may even have to go into a nursing home. 
 There are no firm numbers on the size of this migration of older people back into Westchester. Dr. John N. Migliaccio, president of the American Institute of Financial Gerontology in White Plains, said the phenomenon of reverse migration, which can be found here and across the country, has many implications. This is particularly true in Westchester, where nearly 14 percent of the population is already 65 or older, and where that slice of the population is expected to grow by 30 percent by 2020. In addition, the fastest growing segment of the county's population is made up of those 85 and older. 
 ''The people who are coming back are basically taking their money to Florida and bringing frailty and need for services back to New York,'' Dr. Migliaccio said. ''There's where the relative impact is.'' 
 The elderly population in Westchester is one of the fastest growing in the country. 
 ''Already the demand for services is astronomical,'' Ms. Carpenter said. Beyond that, the challenges to both the returning elderly and the system that serves them are not small. Real estate prices are high and ever rising. There is a constant need in the county for homes for those with low to moderate incomes, and many of the elderly have just such incomes. Transportation shortages and financing that does not keep pace with services needed by the elderly all combine to make a difficult task exasperating for those providing services. 
 In addition, Ms. Carpenter said, older people who might not have needed the county's assistance in the past are starting to require assistance. For example, she said, the downturn in the economy and the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, left some adult children without jobs, making them unable to help their parents financially. Many elderly people had their savings devastated by the stock market debacle a few years ago, she added.
 ''You've got people out in their 80's looking for jobs,'' she said.
 While there are few statistics for Westchester, anecdotally, those who know the situations say returnees are often most noticeable around holidays.
 ''Children go visit their parents, become concerned about their frailty and start looking for places where they can be relocated,'' Ms. Carpenter said.
 Ms. Carpenter said her agency received about 114,000 requests for services last year, quadruple the number of requests in 1998. More than 17,000 people, 10 times the number five years ago, signed up for programs including exercise and medication management, she said.
 Doris Schear, the director of senior housing assistance at Westchester Residential Opportunities, a nonprofit agency working to increase housing for minorities, the elderly, those with psychiatric disabilities, and low- and moderate-income residents, said her group receives many calls from people who are trying to bring their parents to Westchester. Often the parents are in their 80's and in need of at least basic assistance if they are to live on their own while others may need more supervised care or even need to go into a nursing home.
 HOUSING is almost always the biggest concern for those returning. Already Westchester has more than 37,000 elderly households in which the income level is less than that needed to afford median rent.
 For those returning from retirement in places like Florida and Arizona, finding an apartment they can afford can be difficult in an already tight market, and for those who may have owned a home, it may be impossible to buy something comparable here. 
 Although Matilde Cathy Agar, the program coordinator of geriatric outreach for Family Services of Westchester, may be wired into the elderly community as part of her job, she was astounded by what she found two years ago when she tried to relocate an aged aunt who had been living on Long Island with relatives. She found waiting lists of up to 10 years for federally subsidized senior housing on Long Island, and so she began making calls in Westchester where the waiting lists had closed when waits reached five to six years.
 ''I thought it would be challenging to find housing, but it was beyond that,'' Ms. Agar said. ''It was shocking how little was out there.'' 
 Her aunt, Catherine Tomasulo, 88, has an annual income of about $10,000 a year and a plethora of medical needs.
 Ms. Agar was able to find the medical services her aunt needed and talked her into going to My Second Home two days a week for activities, but the housing remained daunting. She said the one-bedroom apartments she found averaged about $1,000 a month, more than her Aunt Katie's entire income. While Ms. Agar was trying to solve the problem, she found out that a construction site she drove by daily was going to be senior housing where residents would be chosen by lottery. Her aunt applied to live at the complex, Wynwood Oaks in Yorktown, and was chosen.
 It has changed her life. Mrs. Tomasulo had become depressed living in a one-room apartment with her nephew. There was nowhere for her to go during the day, no one even to talk with.
 In her new building, she has a spacious one-bedroom apartment, which she keeps immaculate. She likes to cook, and when she needs groceries she can walk down the street to a store. She pays $400 a month, excluding utilities. 
 ''I felt I was living again,'' she said. ''I was by myself and I knew I could do what I want when I want.'' Ms. Carpenter estimated that for the older person living independently in Florida, housing may have cost $300 a month, while here that will often run $1,000 a month at a minimum at market rates.
 ''If we could have all the affordable senior housing we needed indexed to income, many of our problems would be alleviated,'' Ms. Carpenter said.
 Westchester has about 60 federally subsidized apartment buildings throughout the county, most of them in the cities, providing homes for low- and moderate-income elderly, but the waiting lists at those places, which typically have space for about 100 residents, were closed when they reached five or six years.
 While it would be expected that retirees who moved to Florida would be middle class and above and not looking for subsidized housing, whether they can find something on the market within their means is another question. In addition, a common factor prompting the return of an older person may be the death of a spouse, which can result in a serious loss of income.
 The median sales price for a single family house reached $545,500 in Westchester last year and has gone up again this year, according to P. Gilbert Mercurio, the chief executive of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. The median price of a condo reached $322,500 last year and a cooperative, $130,000. In contrast, in 1993, the median sales price of a house in Westchester was $280,000 while the median price of a condo was $160,000.
 Skyrocketing real estate prices have made Ed and Fran Visconti, who raised their family in Eastchester and then moved to Florida in 1987, all the more pleased with their decision to return to the county in 1998. Problematic health and a desire to be near family drove their decision.
 ''In the beginning our children came for all the holidays,'' Mrs. Visconti, 72, said. ''The first five years were fantastic down there, like a vacation.'' 
 But ultimately she missed New York. When the couple returned, they bought a $66,000 one-bedroom co-op and they have become active at a nearby senior center in Eastchester where they both do volunteer work as well as participating.
 At 78, Mr. Visconti said he would like to get his sister, who stayed in Florida, back up here. But the price difference between when he came back and now is making that difficult. 
 ''She keeps saying, 'find me a place like yours,''' Mrs. Visconti said. ''I say, 'You must be kidding.'''
 There are several options for housing in the county. There is plenty of assisted living, programs that provide services like light housekeeping and meals, for those who can afford the price tag of about $30,000 annually and up. Second, many elderly people choose a less expensive apartment and try to patch together services. Third, the elderly with ample money can choose living arrangements that offer what the industry calls a ''continuum of care,'' allowing them to stay in one place as they age or become feeble, offering higher-level services and medical care as needed.
 For now, the Mayones, moving back from Maine, are both healthy. Yet the availability of adult day care like what they found at My Second Home is important. ''It offers teaching programs and interaction with children,'' Mr. Mayone said of the center. ''We looked for a similar program in Connecticut and there's nothing like My Second Home.'' 
 Cathy Mayone, their daughter-in-law, noted that while her in-laws were still self-sufficient, the program will offer a variety of services and activities as they age and require more assistance to get around. Lois Pellegrino, the director of My Second Home, compliments the county for creatingits caregiver resource centers which provide a range of information to the elderly and their families, but says finding services in the northern part of the county, which is more affordable, is very difficult.
 TRANSPORTATION to get her clients to and from the center is expensive and can be problematic for the elderly, whether it is a matter of forgetfulness or simply difficulty getting from their home to a van or cab.
 ''They get to people's homes and they're sleeping,'' she said, providing an example. ''Or somebody has a memory issue and they're not dressed and need assistance.'' 
 While providing services to an ever growing number of the elderly is high on the agenda of social service providers, there is also concern about any increase in demands to the Medicaid program, which covers long-term care for some elderly, and which is escalating rapidly in its cost.
 Just this year the county raised its property taxes 19 percent in large part because of the climbing costs of Medicaid. New York is one of only two states in the country that requires counties to pick up part of the cost of the program and New York has a particularly rich offering of services it covers.
 Ms. Carpenter noted that New York pays more for Medicaid than Texas and California combined, with about 7 to 8 percent of what is being spent in the county going to home and nursing home care. ''It makes it very difficult for counties to want to provide affordable housing if it means they also have to pay the health care costs,'' she said.
 Counties across the state are currently pushing the state to lessen their responsibility for the program. In the meantime, Westchester, with its inordinately large population of the elderly, struggles to cope.
 Still, Ms. Carpenter is quick to note, that those returning are more than welcome.
 ''They were here. They paid their taxes and they moved to cheaper places to live where their dollars go further,'' she said. '' When they become older or frailer they want to be back around their children and friends. It's simply a reality that should be anticipated and planned for.''
 The county has opened nine caregiver resource centers throughout the county, which provide support to aging relatives, but Ms. Carpenter noted there is still no dedicated funds for social adult day services, which can help older people who try to stay in their home rather than being placed in more expensive assisted living centers or nursing homes.
 The county has expanded in-home services for people who do not need supervision with medication, and many groups provide meals to the elderly who are house-bound or day programs for those who can get out. Such costs are paid by the county in addition to Medicaid. 
 The Viscontis go regularly to the Eastchester Senior Citizen Nutrition Program at Lake Isle. Mrs. Visconti helps count the money from the lunch program twice a week and her husband delivers meals to shut-ins.
 Mrs. Visconti said she was worried when she first pressed her husband about coming back to Westchester because moving to Florida after retirement had been his dream.
 But, she said, he couldn't be happier. As for her, she said, there was never any doubt about where she ultimately belonged.
 Never one to mince words, she said, ''I wanted to die in New York.''

Lives That Touch in Shared Space
 FOR five years after her husband became ill, Retta Harper lived with him in a nursing home. It was a sheltered life, in which the nursing home basically cared for her, too.
 When he died, though, she had to leave the nursing home in Purdys, in northern Westchester. But for where? 
 ''The nursing home took every penny we had,'' said Mrs. Harper, who will turn 89 at the end of this month. 
 The couple had no children and living with other relatives was not an option in her mind. Social workers were adamant that she not be on her own, but on her income -- limited to Social Security and a modest pension -- it was questionable whether she could even find a suitable apartment.
 After nearly six months of searching, during which she was allowed to stay in the nursing home, social workers found Mrs. Harper a place to live with A-HOME, a nonprofit group in northern Westchester working to create low-income housing for the elderly as well as single-parent families and people with mental disabilities. The group, which was founded in 1985 and receives support from a coalition of 26 civic organizations and religious groups, buys up large old houses, rehabilitates them and then creates shared housing. Each resident gets a room, but the kitchen, living room and dining room are communal.
 ''They can live together, they look after each other, they can or not share meals together,'' said Joan Arnold, one of the founders.
 The rents are affordable, about 30 percent of the resident's income, and for those in need of services there are either caseworkers or volunteers to help out.
 For Mrs. Harper, who lives in a carriage house the group rehabilitated in Thornwood, that has meant that as health issues have arisen she has had the help to get the services she needs. A nurse visits twice a week and, on a more personal note, as a Roman Catholic, she gets house calls from a nun and a priest.
 The arrangement sounds ideal, but the group can only do so much. It takes about three years once a property is acquired to get it up and operating. In addition, A-Home is limited to an extent by zoning. In some communities, only two unrelated individuals can live in a home, while others allow more. A-HOME serves only about 75 people, 40 of them elderly.
 No other group in the county does quite what A-HOME does on the scale that it does, providing housing and also relying on volunteers to provide services like errand-running and even curtain-making, said Doris Schear, director of senior housing assistance for Westchester Residential Opportunities, a nonprofit group committed to expanding low- and moderate-income housing options. Other groups in the county recycle old buildings into housing, and some also provide services in senior buildings, mostly on a smaller scale, but A-HOME is ''unique and exemplary,'' she said. 
 ''When they say 'A Home,' they mean it,'' she said. ''It's like a little cooperative.''
 A-HOME, which has a waiting list of about a year, is looking to expand beyond the eight houses it has for the elderly, but amid the current housing boom in Westchester County, it is running into increasing competition for the type of big house it likes to convert.
 While A-Home has seen some examples of older people returning after retiring to other places, most of its residents are local people who never left. Beyond that, Ms. Arnold said, a disturbing trend has emerged in recent years: more elderly people are being referred from homeless shelters.
 Mrs. Harper, who has been with A-Home for seven years, said she has no intention of returning to a nursing home.
 ''I wouldn't go back,'' she said. ''I'm too old. They'll have to carry me out of here in a box.'' BARBARA WHITAKER

LENGTH: 695 words

HEADLINE: On Fast Forward, With a Full Nest

BYLINE: By AMY RACKEAR. 
Amy Rackear, an adoption social worker, lives in South Salem.

 BODY:
EVERY weekday morning at 11:35, I wave goodbye to the driver of the school bus and her most special passenger, my daughter, Tamar, as she takes her to kindergarten. ''Have a good afternoon,'' I say to both. ''See you soon.'' Four hours later she will return. ''How was your day?'' I'll ask then, thinking, ''Short, too short,'' while I listen to Tamar's breathless account. 
 I was unemployed when Ari, my oldest, entered school, but my days and nights were full. I returned to the workplace a year later. 
 I am an adoption social worker, responsible for assessing those who seek parenthood through this particular journey. Now, during Tamar's brief absence, I am upstairs in my home office, fingers flying across the keyboard writing an evaluation. 
 My clients live throughout the greater New York metropolitan area and well beyond. To meet them and see their homes, these houses and apartments with an empty room or a study envisioned as a nursery, I have driven as far east as Island Park and north of Albany. 
 Months or sometimes years later, my mind goes with them when they travel to meet their children and finally, bring them home. Some will stay within our borders and others will go to countries like Russia, China, Guatemala, Ethiopia and Kazakhstan. Most governments mandate a follow-up visit after the family's homecoming to determine how all members are adjusting. 
 On one such recent visit, a beaming mother brought her new son into the living room where I sat. ''This is Amy,'' she said to the baby, cradled peacefully in arms that had ached for so long just to hold him. ''She's your fairy godmother.'' It is joyful work. 
 Our days seem to be programmed on fast forward, and I stretch each one well into the next morning. Work deadlines must be met, but my children's needs must not be sacrificed. Years ago, when my son and I were at the kitchen table, a work-related call interrupted our conversation. He said sadly, ''Mom, you spend more time helping people have children than you do with your own.'' It was his perception and, too often, our poignant reality. 
 As my children grow older and their schedules change, I adjust my routine, accordingly. When Tamar was in full-time preschool, I did my field work and wrote reports during the day.
 This year, so I can spend time with her before and after school, I see clients in the evening and on weekends, when my husband is home with the children. On nights when I have no appointments, I am usually writing a report left unfinished at 3:35 on that or another afternoon. 
 My seventh grader's needs are qualitatively different from those of the boy he was only yesterday. With a cellphone in his backpack, Ari might call to tell me about a change in after-school plans, or even to relay a test score. He may have a question or concern. I want to be on the other end of that particular call. 
 One Thursday, I knew that the phone would ring and that it would be Ari. ''Mom, did you finish your report?'' he asked. ''Can you come to my lacrosse game?'' Again, I have to tell him no. The human stork, as he calls me, must continue to work. The next afternoon a tearful Tamar runs from the bus into my arms. ''It's Zane's birthday party,'' she said, sobbing. ''Now, right now, Mommy!'' My certainty that she was invited is matched by zero recall. I reach the parent of another kindergartner. I find out that yes, it's at a gym, and that she would be happy to drive Tamar there. 
 I wipe my daughter's eyes, hastily wrap a present bought for emergencies, and create a card. When the mother arrives to pick up Tamar, we are ready. ''You work so hard,'' she says, trying to both comfort me and ease my guilt. ''It's understandable.'' 
 Several times a month, prospective parents sit across from me. More often than not, both work. ''What will you do about child care?'' I routinely ask. They have anticipated the question, and cite the Family and Medical Leave Act, supportive supervisors, reduced hours when work resumes and, sometimes, the chance to work from home.
 I make my notes while I wonder if my daughter's soccer team is winning, if my son completed his homework, and who will be awake when I return home.

HEADLINE: Made, Not Necessarily Grown, in Connecticut

BYLINE: By HARLAN J. LEVY

 BODY:
THE State Legislature, in a move that all but acknowledges that Connecticut's wine industry can't consistently grow enough grapes to sustain itself under existing laws, voted late last month to reduce by half the amount of home-grown grapes that must make up the wine produced by the state's vineyards.
 On April 27, the Legislature voted to reduce the home-grown requirement to 25 percent from 51 percent beginning on Oct. 1. After that, some of the state's wines will be allowed to import more grapes from such places as California, Long Island and upstate New York.
 ''We had to do it,'' said State Representative Leonard C. Greene, a Republican of Beacon Falls who sponsored the bill, which was awaiting the governor's signature late last week. ''The commissioner of the Department of Consumer Protection contacted me and explained that a lot of the farm wineries were not meeting the 51 percent standard, so he thought that in order to preserve the Connecticut Wine Trail and tourism in Connecticut we should help them out. Because of the climate and the amount they are producing they could not keep up with that 51 percent standard.'' 
 Without this change, Edwin R. Rodriguez, the consumer protection commissioner, said his agency would have had to revoke or suspend most of the wineries' licenses. He said that a survey taken during an ongoing investigation by the Liquor Control Commission of the wineries found that almost all of them failed to meet the 51 percent requirement. That meant they faced losing their annual retail sales permits.
 ''To me, that's a detriment to the Connecticut economy, and they do play a critical role in bringing tourism to the state,'' he said.
 Indeed, the State Division of Tourism logs significant numbers of people visiting the wine trail section of its Web site. ''The wine trail brochure is one of the most popular at the state Welcome Centers,'' said Edward Dombroskas, the division director. ''The wineries are a very important element of the tourism product.''
 Jonathan Edwards, the founder of Jonathan Edwards Winery in North Stonington and president of the Connecticut Vineyard and Winery Association, said about 5,000 to 6,000 visitors tour his winery from June 1 to mid-November, the high season for Connecticut's 18 wineries. These tourists account for 80 percent to 85 percent of the Edwards winery's retail sales and a similar portion for its competitors. Losing those customers would be devastating, he said.
 ''Just about every winery on the wine trail is heavily dependent on retail sales at the winery, so if you can't make retail sales, you're pretty well out of business,'' he said.
 The investigation, sparked after Sherman Haight, owner of Haight Vineyard in Litchfield, acknowledged last year that some of his wines were made mostly from Chilean grape concentrate, found that because of the climate and inevitable weather problems, the wineries can only produce 20 to 30 percent of the grapes they need. For example, Mr. Edwards said that this past winter's cold spell might have killed 25 percent of last season's grapes. ''We have no other alternatives,'' Mr. Edwards said about last month's legislation. ''They really want a vibrant industry, so they're following the lead of other states that don't restrict the percentage of grapes.''
 There's a simple supply problem, said Eugene Spaziani, president of the local chapter of the national wine society Amenti del Vino and a critic and wine judge who has monitored Connecticut wines since 1985. ''There are just not enough grape growers in Connecticut to satisfy the needs of the Connecticut wineries,'' he said.
 The new law mandates that at least 25 percent of the grapes a winery uses a year must be home-grown. That doesn't mean every bottle must contain at least the 25 percent; the law just affects a winery's total output.
 Winery owners said that lowering the percentage is not an effort to prop up failing enterprises. Rather, it's an honest reflection of vineyard economics.
 Planting grapes is expensive, and it requires three to five years for them to mature, said Gary Crump, co-owner and winemaker of Priam Vineyards of Colchester and vice president of the winery association. ''It takes $15,000 to $30,000 an acre,'' he said, and finding capital is tough, because commercial lenders won't wait for repayment until after the mature fruit is harvested.
 Lowering the restriction will lead to more home-grown grapes, not less, said Steven Vollweiler, owner of Sharpe Hill Vineyard of Pomfret. ''By allowing us to make more wine, we can be more profitable and we can reinvest in our own vineyards and make them larger, but you need the revenue to grow,'' he said.
 Mr. Edwards said many other states don't have grape quotas.
 ''We're not just competing with Connecticut wineries; we're competing with California, New York, Australia, Chile, France, and New Zealand,'' he said. ''Why should Connecticut impose stricter regulations on me?''
 Growth at the expense of consumers is the main concern of Attorney General Richard Blumenthal.
 ''I'm sympathetic to the need to permit the potential use of out-of-state grapes, but the consumer should be accurately and completely informed,'' Mr. Blumenthal said. ''If the wine contains only 25 percent Connecticut grapes, consumers have a right to know.''
 However, the revised law does not require the label to say the percentage of Connecticut grapes used.
 ''It was kind of late to put it in,'' Mr. Greene said. ''That's something we probably have to look at next year.''
 More labeling is not needed, winery owners said, because federal labeling laws are adequate. When a label has the word ''Connecticut'' before a type of wine, 75 percent of that wine must come from Connecticut grapes. Also, the name of a vineyard can be used on a wine label only if 95 percent of that wine comes from that vineyard's grapes. These requirements do not change under the new home-grown standard.
 But to Robert Chaplin, a wine critic and columnist who has tasted all of the state wines over the last 15 years, it is ''imperative'' to tell consumers where the grapes come from, he said.
 ''I understand that if there's inclement weather, the vineyards should have the option to buy other grapes, but it's got to be labeled as such,'' he said. ''What's the problem with doing that unless you're trying to hide something?''
 Additional information may be needed on labels, Mr. Blumenthal said, but common sense should prevail. ''I have no desire to be the state's wine czar, so we'll simply review complaints that are presented,'' he said.
 Obtaining grapes from outside Connecticut will not reduce quality, Mr. Spaziani said, predicting that Long Island will be a major source.
 ''Long Island is a wine jewel,'' he said. ''They're growing tremendous grapes, and the red grapes they can get from California are superior to the ones we can grow here because of weather conditions.''
 Over all, Connecticut wines have an excellent reputation, according to the two wine critics. ''The quality is astounding, especially the whites and even the reds,'' Mr. Chaplin said. The top vineyards are making world-class wines, he said. ''Chamard, Hopkins, Stonington, Sharpe Hill, Priam -- they make remarkable wines.''
 Not all Connecticut wines are medal-winners, Mr. Spaziani said, ''but they're holding their own, in some cases, with wines from all over the world, and they're all judged blind. That's amazing.''
 The marketplace will judge, Mr. Crump said. ''The quality of the wine speaks for itself.''

HEADLINE: Lower Manhattan, On the Rise

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY. 
RANDY KENNEDY reports on cultural news for The Times.

 BODY:
THE key word in Lower Manhattan right now -- emblazoned on expensive banners and posters hanging at what seems to be every street corner -- is ''renew.''
 It has been more than two and half years since the Sept. 11 attacks. And in that time the landscape of destruction has been given over so completely to rebuilding that you could be forgiven for considering the whole island south of Canal Street to be one vast hard-hat zone, relieved by the occasional patch of unjackhammered pavement.
 So when I played the tourist in my own city in the first days of spring, I decided to use this theme of rebuilding to my advantage. Yes, it will be years before the major projects around the World Trade Center site are finished and neighborhoods feel whole again, but I wanted to discover the things that are already beginning to emerge, in a sense, from the scaffolding -- the brand-new, the relatively new or at least the recently renewed, beckoning people back downtown. I found that even in a city defined by the quantity of its novelty, Lower Manhattan is spilling over with places that have that unmistakable new-car smell. 
 Of course, the economic effects of the attacks haven't vanished completely. The Regent Wall Street, one of the area's most elegant hotels and one that served as a kind of canteen for rescue workers in 2001, closed in January after its owners said they could no longer withstand their losses. There are still fewer restaurants in the area than there were in September 2001, though the numbers are rising again. The Screening Room, for example, a restaurant and movie theater that had been operating for seven years on Varick Street near Canal Street, closed last fall after months of losses, but Robert De Niro and the other founders of the TriBeCa Film Festival are using it for screenings. 
 I started my tour by spending a recent Sunday at a place that is a case in point of the shiny possibilities of the new Lower Manhattan: the Millenium Hilton Hotel. The collapse of the World Trade Center towers shattered more than 100 windows in the dark-glass-sheathed hotel, which was right across Church Street. 
 The hotel finally reopened last spring, and staying in it recently felt like getting to test-market a new toy. The lobby's polished honey-toned wood, sleek couches and elongated tube-shaped chandeliers give it somewhat of a boutique-hotel feel, but on a grander scale, and that feeling continues up into the rooms, all of which present a nice surprise: a 42-inch plasma TV screen in the wall.
 In many Manhattan-scaled hotel rooms, the sheer size of such a television would feel like an Orwellian intrusion. But because the Millenium's rooms have large windows with great views of sky and city, the television just seems like an extra view, with a remote control. (In the nearby Ritz-Carlton in Battery Park City, the area's other luxury hotel, the harbor-view rooms come with a more low-tech viewing device: a telescope, for close-ups of the Statue of Liberty. The Best Western Seaport Inn on Peck Slip also has rooms with fantastic Brooklyn Bridge views, at a much cheaper rate.)
 My corner room at the Millenium -- for which I paid an early spring discount rate of $179, one of the best deals in the city -- was on the 52nd floor, with one window looking out over the harbor and Liberty Island and the other giving me a long view up the East River, with the crenellated Woolworth Building in the foreground and the Brooklyn Bridge shimmering in the distance. In a corner of the harbor-view window, I could also see the gargantuan World Trade Center site, laced with ramps and train tracks and the steel skeleton of the new 7 World Trade Center tower beginning to rise.
 Not to overstate the case, but there is really nothing quite like watching ''The Sopranos'' on a ridiculously huge plasma television with the lights turned low while nighttime New York City sparkles like diamonds outside your windows. Aside from the fact that my room was a little too close to the elevator shaft, which frequently emitted a drone like something out of ''Star Trek,'' it was a dream hotel experience.
 As hotel restaurants go, the Millenium's -- called Church & Dey, for the hotel's intersection -- is fine, but with TriBeCa just up the street, it's a better idea to walk north.
 One night my wife, Janet, and I tried Azafran, a Spanish restaurant on Warren Street serving the cuisine of San Sebastian, the Basque seaside spot that is less a town than a temple of food worship. We stayed there a couple of years ago, and while Azafran only rarely approached the real thing, it was enough to bring back great memories -- with marinated anchovies, chorizo and very tasty shrimp skewered with dates.
 You could also get a very good pizza or bowl of pasta at Bread Tribeca on Church Street, which opened last year. Befitting its once-industrial neighborhood, the restaurant is a pale, stripped-down, airy place, with the kitchen in full view and wine barrels hanging behind the bar.
 Near the bar hung yet another huge flat-screen television with the sound off. The night I stopped in for a drink Charles Laughton's ''Night of the Hunter'' was playing, the spooky 1955 black-and-white movie starring Robert Mitchum as a murderous preacher. The effect was quite strange, something like an animated ''American Gothic.'' 
 By then, instead of new and eager, I needed a dose of old and tenacious. So I headed to Walker's, at North Moore and Varick Streets, which has been a bar of one sort or another since 1877 and which, even after 11 on Sunday night, was packed with a young crowd. The bartender's two-tone gray and jet-black hairdo was almost entertaining enough to make you forget that the owner of the hairdo was ignoring you. Of course, being ignored at a place as beer-stained as Walker's is a New York birthright. It gave me new hope for the neighborhood.
 The next weekend, I returned, and set out to get a view of Lower Manhattan from a different perspective.
 I considered the Skyscraper Museum, which opened April 2 in a beautiful new permanent space in Battery Park City. But you don't even have to go the museum to see some of its work: It has helped create an installation around two edges of the World Trade Center site -- on Church and Liberty Streets -- that recounts the history of Lower Manhattan, tells the story of the Trade Center and explains the rebuilding effort.
 I also thought about another place-appropriate museum, the Museum of American Financial History near Wall Street. Among the exhibits is a working hand-operated intaglio press (or spider) of the kind used in the late 1800's and early 1900's to print bank notes and other financial documents.
 But it was a sunny day after a long, dark winter. And so I went to the South Street Seaport, where I joined a small crowd waiting to board a brand-new tour boat, the Zephyr, operated by Circle Line Harbor Cruises, part of the same company that operates the hugely popular ferries to Liberty Island. The Statue of Liberty, which has been closed to tourists since the Sept. 11 attacks, is scheduled to reopen sometime in July, though the crown will remain closed; Liberty Island itself is open to tourists.
 The Zephyr is 143 feet long, all smoky glass and polished hull. It can accommodate up to 600 passengers and, unlike many of the tour boats that ply the harbor, it hums along quietly atop four water-jets. Inside, it definitely still has that new-car -- or in this case new catamaran -- smell. There are comfortable turquoise-blue seats, tiny drink tables and (here they come again) flat-panel televisions. Hanging near the mahogany bar and the orchids in vases that decorated the main deck, they successfully created a P. Diddy private-yacht atmosphere.
 ''When we first started running tours, we had to put out a sandwich board saying, 'Open to the Public,' because people just assumed it was a private boat,'' said Capt. Russell Bostock, the director of operations for the cruise company.
 Its tours run up the East River to the Williamsburg Bridge, where the Empire State Building makes its appearance. Then the boat turns around, hits speeds of over 30 miles an hour heading out into the harbor, skims near Liberty Island and docks again at the Seaport. This month, the company will also run a faster boat called the Shark out of Pier 16. ''People get wet, the stereo's blaring away and sometimes the pilot dresses up like a pirate,'' said Captain Bostock, describing the tours. ''You know, fun stuff.''
 I had had enough fun by that point to build up an appetite, so I once again wandered a bit off the topic and almost out of the geographical boundary by walking through Chinatown to a small, crowded restaurant near the entrance to the Manhattan Bridge called Great New York Noodletown. The flowering chives and soft-shell crabs there are incredible. But with a chill in the air, I went for something more substantial, a congee, or porridge, with frog's legs (not my everyday lunch, but sometimes frog hits the spot) followed by a clay-pot lamb casserole with bean-curd skin and a Tsingtao beer.
 I ended the day by bisecting Lower Manhattan, cutting back across Chinatown and TriBeCa and wending my way alongside ground zero. The site continues to attract a huge weekend crowd, some of whom buy tickets for the PATH train so they can walk into the temporary, open-air station, descend 70 feet to the platforms, and look at the Trade Center foundation from inside the so-called bathtub wall, an awesome sight.
 But I was there to revisit the Winter Garden in the World Financial Center, which I had not seen since Sept. 7, 2001, when I was there to conduct an interview.
 The 10-story atrium, which was heavily damaged in the attack, reopened in 2002, looked just as I'd remembered it, though polished up a bit. It's a wonder anyone can get to it -- the entrance to the Vesey Street pedestrian bridge over West Street was so crowded with vendors selling fake designer watches and other trinkets it felt like a souk.
 But the Winter Garden itself felt like an oasis, full of light and people, and outside near it there was another garden, this one with newly blossomed daffodils and an inviting expanse of green grass next to the North Cove Yacht Harbor.
 As the sun started to climb down the sky, I lay down on the grass and overheard a group of friends debating endlessly whether to eat in TriBeCa or Chinatown or maybe catch a ferry to Brooklyn to find something cool there.
 They finally decided to stay in Lower Manhattan and try to find someplace new. I wanted to tell them it was not going to be hard at all. 

Just the tip of it

HEADLINE: Flight Notes

 BODY:

To the Editor: As the largest distributor of European rail passes in North America, we would like to expand upon the information about European rail passes versus the low-cost air carriers that appeared in ''The New World of Cut-Rate Fares,'' by Katherine Zoepf (April 4).
 Although the best known, the Eurailpass is not the only rail pass available and is a poor point of comparison for travelers going between a very limited number of destinations in Europe. There are economical rail passes for one, two or three countries or more -- a rail pass for just about any itinerary and any budget. An American quoted in the article complained about a $500 Europass (Europasses were discontinued in 2002) and how she did all her traveling by night on the trains -- which would lead readers to believe this is the general case for rail-pass buyers. The truth is there are many far less expensive rail passes available and traveling by night is not required.
 Certainly when only making one round trip between Point A and B, a cut-rate air carrier will be less costly than a rail pass -- but so is a point-to-point rail ticket. Eurostar now offers plenty of $90 round trips between London and Brussels with free connection to Bruges or elsewhere in Belgium. The rail ticket also eliminates the expense and hassle of a trip to and from the airports at either end since train stations are usually in the city center. A rail pass offers the flexibility to explore an area and to change your itinerary without having to check for local specials -- and without paying extra.
 Incidentally, readers cannot follow Ms. Zoepf's specific example because the Ryanair flight she wrote about, Stansted-Ostend, was discontinued Jan. 14, which Ryanair announced in December. 

NICO ZENNER
Vice President, Marketing
Rail Europe Group
White Plains

HEADLINE: The Other Side Of the Trade Deficit

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re ''The Tale of the Toaster, or How Trade Deficits Are Good'' (Everybody's Business, April 25), which suggested that trade deficits and the sale of government securities to foreign countries have a positive effect on the United States economy:
 I am troubled by glossing over the long-term dangers of our nation's seemingly perennial (but by no means necessary) trade deficit. Supplying consumers through lower-cost imports is a benefit of free trade itself, not trade deficits, and preaching the virtues of having a foreign buying pool for Treasury securities is akin to saying that alcoholics benefit society by providing a customer base for liquor stores.

Alexander Skora
Mountain Lakes, N.J., April 26

The writer is president of Estron Chemical.

HEADLINE: Changing All The Rules

 BODY:
 Bruce Barcott (April 4) claims to have conducted ''extensive interviews with those involved'' in the reform of the Clean Air Act's new source review (N.S.R.) program. But Barcott couldn't find us or dozens of other knowledgeable sources that could have challenged the jaundiced view of N.S.R. presented by the disgruntled former enforcement officers he chose to interview. He couldn't even be bothered to return our phone call. 
 It shows.
 First, an inflexible approach to N.S.R. is counterproductive, if the goal is actually reducing emissions and not just perpetuating litigation. Experts from major research universities, think-tanks, labor unions and minority organizations -- as well as state officials and representatives of 20 different industries -- have concluded that an N.S.R. program that discourages maintenance activities reduces energy efficiency and actually increases emissions! 
 Even the cover is highly misleading. It's a close-up photo of the top of a stack with a backlit white plume. Large type over the photo says, ''Up in Smoke.'' The plume is actually steam from the scrubber system that removes up to 98 percent of sulfur dioxide emissions. Ironically, plants without scrubbers emit hundreds of thousands of tons more SO2 but look less dramatic in photos and video. ''Up in Steam'' just isn't as catchy, we suppose.
 Barcott implies that industry was aware it could be violating N.S.R. prior to the lawsuits filed in 1999. Wrong. The Clinton administration's E.P.A. itself wrote in 1997 that ''few, if any, changes typically made to existing steam generating units would be expected'' to trigger N.S.R. A recent federal court ruling says that the ''E.P.A. may have spoken out of both sides of its mouth''; there is no reason to believe that the E.P.A. properly placed industry on notice of the agency's view of the law. The government and environmentalists actually concluded that case was unwinnable just a few weeks ago.
 Utilities have made billions of dollars in investments in pollution control in recent years, substantially improving environmental performance. Federal and state law have established an effective regulatory framework quite independent of N.S.R. 
 The E.P.A. reports that since 1970, total emissions of the six major air pollutants fell 48 percent. These air-quality improvements occurred even as the economy grew by 164 percent and energy consumption by 42 percent. 
 While improvements can always be made, the news is pretty good. But you'd never know it to read Barcott's one-sided article.

Scott Segal
Washington
 (Segal is director of the Electric Reliability Coordinating Council, which represents utilities opposed to the enforcement of New Source Review rules.)

SECTION: Section 1; Column 3; National Desk; Pg. 16; CAMPAIGN 2004: BOSTON CONVENTION

LENGTH: 1449 words

HEADLINE: Both Parties Wear Smiles for Democrats' Convention Site

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
The capital of this northeastern, union-heavy state may not seem the best locale for the Democratic Party to nominate Senator John Kerry, a hometown hero. After all, if Mr. Kerry were a preacher, Massachusetts would be his choir.
 At the same time, there is no better backdrop for Republicans hoping to cast Mr. Kerry as an out-of-touch Ted Kennedy liberal than a coronation focusing the nation's attention on a state that is expected to be the first allowing gay marriages.
 What's more, grumbling can already be heard in the choir loft -- police officers without contracts are threatening to picket outside the convention and residents are worried about commuter chaos all around it. 
 So, all things being equal, the Democratic Party might have gotten a little lift if its presidential nominating convention in July were being held elsewhere, in some battleground state like Ohio or Pennsylvania, said Rod O'Connor, chief executive of the Democratic National Convention Committee. But, he said, for the mass of voters across the country, the selection of a convention site has little meaning compared with the message that comes out of the event.
 ''Besides, Cleveland didn't bid this time,'' Mr. O'Connor said. ''Miami did, New York did and Detroit did. And we decided to come here.''
 It will be months before it is known whether that choice -- made long before it became clear that Mr. Kerry would be the nominee -- was a wise one for Democrats, but there is no shortage of opinions in the meantime.
 ''I think having the convention in Boston is a terrible decision,'' said Edward I. Koch, the former New York mayor. It would have been much better to have the gathering in New York, he said, tapping into the party's populous heart and refusing to cede Sept. 11 symbolism to the Republicans, who will have their convention in New York starting in late August.
 In defending the selection, some Democrats insist that Boston's image as America's birthplace will ring enough patriotic bells to drown out any Republican mischief.
 ''Boston is the home of the first public school, the first public library and the birthplace of freedom in this country,'' Mr. O'Connor said. ''Those are excellent backdrops to talk about education, to talk about personal freedom.''
 But already, Republicans are trying to link Mr. Kerry with his home state through the Boston Fog Report, a series of e-mail statements sent en masse by the Bush campaign to journalists and Republicans to paint Mr. Kerry as obscuring the record and flip-flopping on issues, as well as being a Massachusetts liberal.
 Ed Gillespie, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said, ''The fact that they are having their convention in Boston does help reinforce that, especially if voters who watch the convention come away with a perception of a Democratic Party that is going back to its traditional liberal roots.''
 And then there is the gay marriage issue, which Republican leaders believe will cause many independents to support President Bush.
 Massachusetts has been at the center of the controversy since the state's highest court ruled that same-sex marriage would become legal on May 17. Gov. Mitt Romney, a Republican, and the Democratic-controlled legislature both support a ban on gay marriage, but thousands of reporters will descend on Boston to cover the convention long before the Constitution can be amended.
 In a theory more hopeful for Democrats, advanced by Boston boosters, far from being a liability, holding the convention here will be a boon for Mr. Kerry. Having a hometown candidate will energize the convention, Mr. O'Connor said, and that enthusiasm will be apparent on television.
 ''I can remember my mother making me stay up when John Kennedy won the nomination in 1960,'' said City Councilor Maureen E. Feeney, a Democrat who is the Council's convention liaison. ''I can remember us running out and dancing in the streets. I guess part of the enthusiasm that people in Boston are feeling is that for them, like me, there is that little girl who is saying, hey, it could happen again.''
 For all the discussion, local officials and campaign scholars play down the importance of the convention's location in the outcome of the election.
 ''Oh, I don't think the site of the convention means a lot,'' said Thomas M. Menino, Boston's three-term Democratic mayor who, along with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, spearheaded the drive to have the convention here. ''The important thing is, What's the message? It's not so much about the convention itself, it's about the message that comes out of the convention about what the party stands for.''
 Then there is the message the world could get about Boston. The city, in contract negotiations with its public workers, is locked in increasingly contentious talks with the union representing 1,400 police officers. The union, forbidden to strike, is threatening to picket outside the convention, being held in the Fleet Center, turning the event into one grand platform for airing its grievances.
 [When the city announced rules in early May for convention week protests, police union officials and civil libertarians called them an attempt to silence dissent.]
 Mr. O'Connor said Democrats were optimistic that the labor troubles would be resolved before the opening gavel on July 26. Mayor Menino, sounding a more cautious note, would say only that he expected to have concluded most of the negotiations by then.
 But Thomas J. Nee, president of the Boston Police Patrolmen's Association, warned that police unions from around the country had agreed to send uniformed officers to join in the picketing if the dispute was not over by then.
 ''We will be out in the street, there is no doubt about that,'' Mr. Nee said. 
 While police pickets are a possibility, commuter headaches are a certainty.
 Security concerns will force the temporary closing of portions of I-93, a downtown artery running along one side of the Fleet Center, tying up traffic throughout the region. And because one of the city's main commuter rail links, North Station, lies just beneath the spot where Mr. Kerry will accept the nomination it also will be closed, adding to commuters' woes.
 ''For the players, the inside people, this is all very exciting, an incredible opportunity,'' said Ms. Feeney, the councilwoman. ''But to the average citizen trying to get to work every day, it's a somewhat different story.''
 Some 35,000 people are expected to attend the July 26-29 event, including 5,000 delegates and alternates and 15,000 members of the news media.
 A study by the Boston Redevelopment Authority's Office of Budget Management concluded that the four-day event will add $154.2 million to the regional economy. But another study, by the Beacon Hill Institute at Suffolk University, found that the economy will suffer a net loss of more than $12 million after factoring in costs from the transportation inconveniences and the loss of other summer events, like the United States Olympic gymnastic trials, which was moved after the city was selected for the convention.
 But the impact on the city will go well beyond any balance sheet, convention and city officials say. With a new convention center about to open across town from the Fleet Center, Boston officials hope to use the Democratic event as one vast promotion. 
 ''It is a great opportunity for a city to showcase itself,'' Mr. O'Connor said.
 Indeed, the opening-night parties -- normally held at the hotels where the delegations are housed -- will be scattered throughout the city's neighborhoods, in places like a bakery, a brewery, a bathhouse and historic homes, museums and parks, said Julie Burns, executive director of Boston 2004, the host committee.
 Perhaps it is best that not all attention will be on the convention itself, because the image there is not entirely the one the city had hoped. The razing of a decrepit, elevated rail line is behind schedule, so conventioneers will have to pass beneath the rotting hulk to get inside the Fleet Center.
 For all the problems and promise of the Boston convention, the perils it poses for Democrats may pale compared to those that Republicans face in New York, a campaign expert says.
 ''If you've got unions protesting outside the Boston convention while Democrats who are pro-union are inside, trying to dance around it, that's a bit of a nightmare,'' said Norman J. Ornstein, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute. ''And it could all come a cropper on the gay marriage issue, if there are gay marriages being performed outside during the convention. But actually, the downside risk is greater for the Republicans in New York if issues are raised about exploiting 9/11.''

HEADLINE: Fighting the Falls To Rope in Tourists

BYLINE: By JANON FISHER

DATELINE: Paterson 

 BODY:
YOU can't fool nature.
 Just ask William DiPillo, operator of the Great Falls hydroelectric plant in Paterson.
 Two weeks ago, Mr. DiPillo planned to divert 1.2 billion gallons of water from the Passaic River through the 90-year-old power plant, drying up the Great Falls, a waterfall second in size only to Niagara on the East Coast. 
 Mr. DiPillo's effort was part of a clean-up intended to make the Great Falls a more attractive candidate for national park status. Once the power of the falls was used to drive industry -- now local politicians are hoping it is enough to drive a tourist economy. ''What we're trying to do now is to make the Great Falls a destination and therefore downtown Paterson a destination and the hinterlands around there a destination,'' said Rep. William Pascrell Jr., who sponsored the Congressional bill seeking national park status. 
 But first, there is the small matter of refuse management. The Great Falls is bounded by parkland, and sits at a bend in the Passaic River, where 72 miles of river fall over a 77 foot drop. In that journey the river picks up everything from dead trees to tires.
 Although ridding the area of the debris it invariably collects is not among the formal criteria that the National Park Service weighs in its year-long study of the site, it could not hurt. 
 At the same time, officials are pinning their hopes on the site's history. Alexander Hamilton chose the Great Falls as the site for America's first industrial city in 1791. He organized the Society for Establishing Useful Manufactures, which bought the land to build factories and mills so that the United States could liberate itself from its reliance on manufactured goods from England.
 ''Hamilton knew the spot well,'' Ron Chernow wrote in his biography on Hamilton. ''One day during the Revolution he, Washington, and Lafayette had picnicked by the falls enjoying a 'modest repast' of cold ham, tongue and biscuits in a sylvan setting that momentarily banished thoughts of war.''
 While the Great Falls is still an impressive natural wonder, the city of Paterson -- with its crumbling factories and urban woes -- evokes thoughts of war, not of banishing them. To combat that, the city has embarked on a campaign to rehabilitate mills and factories in the area. Officials see the bid for park status working in tandem with historic rehabilitation. 
 ''Heritage tourism is the hook that brings people back to our historic cities,'' said David Soo, executive director of the Paterson Friends of the Great Falls, a group pushing for national park status.
 Mr. DiPillo was eager to do his part. But the clean-up did not happen exactly the way he had planned. 
 As the plant operator learned, you can't stop a flow of 1600 cubic feet of water per second with the twist of a spigot.
 After an inch and a half of rain fell in the area, with the plant diverting as much water as it could, water rose 20 inches. The falls were raging cascades.
 ''As much as we think we can control things, we have to deal with a little humility,'' said Mr. DiPillo, who acts as a caretaker, operator, educator and all-around ambassador at the plant.
 As such, he has become uncannily familiar with its detritus. 
 ''You can always tell what sport is in season by the type of balls you see floating in the river,'' said Mr. DiPillo, who has found an athletic store's supply of sports balls. A voodoo doll that he found in the fish bypass landed him a profile article in Weird NJ, a magazine that covers Garden State oddities. 
 So with the debris building up, Mr. DiPillo decided that he would plan to shut down the falls on April 30 for his annual Arbor Day clean-up. Every year he invites local children to spend a day planting trees and cleaning the shores around falls. And shutting the falls down, would allow him to call in a clean up crew to remove blockages and repair the 163-year-old dam above the falls. 
 But nature continued to chafe against the will of men: last week it rained again.
 With two of the three turbines operating at capacity, diverting 1275 cubic feet of water per second away from the falls (the third turbine is not operating because of a crack in its 8 foot 6 inch intake pipe), the fish bypass siphoning off another 10 cubic feet per second, the falls had slowed but still provided enough mist to make a rainbow.
 Still, crews were able to remove some logs, trash and debris from the banks and a few low spots that had been created by diverting the water. And they plan to be back this summer during the drier months. 
 For now, Mr. DiPillo and nature appear to be reaching an accord.
